story:
The Pitch

Hi there,

I am Dr. Neville Ellis, human geographer and co-author of UN's IPCC Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5°C (Oct 2018), along with my good mate and collaborator Gwenaël Velge, artist photographer based in Perth, we are looking for support to fund our photographic exhibition cum public lecture series about the Anthropocene: "NowHere: the decisive moment."

Our event is born from a growing recognition that we are living in an extraordinary moment in human and planetary time.

Human impacts on the Earth are profound. We are changing the climate, acidifying the oceans and erasing ecosystems and species in ways not seen in millions of years. Such is our impact on the environment that there is growing scientific consensus that humanity has pushed the earth into an entirely new geological epoch called the Anthropocene.

"NowHere: the decisive moment" probes the significance of our Anthropocene moment and explores what it means for us to be human upon a human dominated planet.

The exhibition blends Western Australian landscapes and scientific data, taking the audience on an aesthetic and intellectual ride through the deep history of some of the oldest landscapes on earth (older than oxygen on earth...). 

The exhibition will last 3 months and feature 3 public lectures organised around three thematics (science, art&culture and politics) with reputable guest speakers engaging with why our time is so extraordinary and how we might come to tackle the challenges we face. 

How You Can Help and What You Get

We need your help to fund the printing, framing and some designing of the exhibition. 

Support our arts, culture & environment project and get cards and/or archival quality prints in return! 

In other words, receive a part of the meaningful exhibition you are about to help make publicly available!

·      The photographic works represent a retrospective selection of Gwen's work. Some of the pieces are already printed and framed, some are printed but not framed, while others only exist digitally at this stage. We have been quoted $6100 for the required printing and framing.

·      We wish to make the science digestible to the wider public (we estimate over 25,000 pub goers will see the exhibition), we will be working with OOID who specialises in graphic design for science and quoted us $1200 for the work needed. 

·      We hope to raise an additional $500-$1000 for extra running costs (catalogues, promotion, hardware, etc.). 

·      If we do not reach our goal, we will make do with what we have (prints and money): it is that simple. Without the ability to properly design the exhibition, it is likely to not have as strong an impact, but we are committed to making it happen no matter what. 

·      If we go beyond our goal and once all costs have been accounted for, we will be creating a kitty that will either help us to put on a similar event elsewhere, or to support an organisation tackling climate change either locally or abroad. The decision of what to do will largely depend on how successful we are with this event and how much time and energy we can commit to a follow-up event. 

The Necessity, the Impact

As the exhibition argues, we find ourselves at a planetary inflection point. It is the responsibility of the community - especially the arts community - to envision a better future and challenge the status quo. It is the responsibility of the academic community to provide the most up-to-date knowledge about the reality we inhabit in order to steer human actions in the most beneficial and ethical manner. Together, these two overlapping communities have the power to move mountains (or rocks?), not by coercion or sophistry, but by informing and inciting introspective and public reflection. 

The scientific community is near unanimous about the dire ecological moment we find ourselves in. Yet we as a collective seem to lack the economic and political impetus to undertake meaningful action. We believe that the key to the challenges we face is to facilitate and incite strong community participation and involvement. We believe that these cultural events, mixing visual arts, engaging infographics and live forums, can meaningfully facilitate this planetary undertaking. It should happen Now, Here.

"NowHere" is a genuine opportunity to reach a large number of people with a meaningful and digestible message at relatively low 'cost' to the individual supporter (i.e. high bang for your $). The cost of the venue and the audience it naturally attracts (+-2,000-2,500 people a week, possibly 30,000 people over the length of the exhibition) are free of charge thanks to the support of The National Hotel. The art, skill and knowledge of Gwenael and Neville are passionately given for free to this event. "NowHere" is thus likely to both present these works and data to an audience who may not have been exposed to it previously, and it also serves as a basis for community consolidating events with the public lectures we propose to put on. Science, art and politics need to work together to imagine and deliver desirable and resilient futures for all: let's make it happen with this exhibition and public lectures.  

The Team

Neville was a Contributing Author and Chapter Scientist on the IPCC Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5°C. He has published in prestigious academic journals such as Nature and Nature Climate Change, and is an awarded public speaker (see his TEDx Talk here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jwPSdmy8H8Y). Neville is passionate about science communication and working with communities to imagine climate-resilient and sustainable futures. 

Gwen has a strong record in producing lateral thinking exhibitions, especially in the last couple years ("Homing the Unhomely" and "1:81"). He is also know to make stuff happen, he has a suite of uni degrees (Bachelor of Psychology, Honours Sociology, Honours International Relations, MA Peace and Dvpt Studies, and still trying to finish his PhD), has had two successful small businesses and continues to try to produce events like these which he believes help make this world a better place. 

Other Ways You Can Help

As with most community lead enterprises, success occurs by getting the community talking.

If you do not have the means to financially support our project, then you can still help us out by sharing, commenting and talking about our project with friends and family members. Also, please feel free to put us in touch with others who might be willing and able to help (time, social capital, political capital etc.).

Whatever it is that you think you can do, make it personal! Add a personal note to your share or your introduction of our project to friends, family or colleagues. This will better convey that you actually care ;-) 

And that's all there is to it. Let us know if you have any questions.

Choose your print: 

 

1. 

 

2.

 

3. 

 

4.

 

5.

story:
1. L’Happening/installazione

 

Dal 14 al 19 novembre 2017, in occasione della conferenza TEDxBari sul tema del “disordine”, Spazio Murat ha ospitato Bazar Elettrico in Action: un’esperienza filosofica e artistica nata dalla ricerca del collettivo Action30 e co-prodotta con l’associazione Cu.Bo.

Schedati e fotografati all’interno di un tunnel, muniti di guanti in lattice e coperte termiche, i partecipanti sono catapultati in una situazione surreale. Un ammasso di rovine li accoglie come un totem minaccioso e sospeso nel tempo. Alcuni sorridono incuriositi, altri non riescono a dissimulare un certo disagio.

La catastrofe è solo il punto di partenza. Il gioco comincia qui.

 

Ph.: Giuseppe Santoro

 

Oltre 500 persone hanno partecipato all’esperienza realizzata a Bari dal collettivo Action30, in collaborazione con gli studenti del liceo artistico “Pascali-De Nittis” e gli ospiti minori e adulti del Progetto Sprar (Sistema protezione richiedenti asilo e rifugiati) di Bari.

 

 
Un articolo sull'esperienza "B.E. in action", pubblicato sul sito della UAL (University of the Arts London): "Bazar Elettrico – electrifying the present to imagine new futures"
 
 
 

2. L’esperimento e il gioco

 

Che cosa accadrebbe se ripetessimo l’esperienza che – a cavallo degli anni ’20-’30 del secolo scorso – facevano i surrealisti nei mercati delle pulci di Parigi? Che significato avrebbe oggi e che effetti produrrebbe su di noi?

Dopo la catastrofe della I Guerra mondiale, pressati dalla crisi economica e dal fascismo che si diffonde in Europa, i surrealisti si aggirano in trance alla ricerca di oggetti, segnali, strani indizi: tutto quello che, facendo vibrare il loro desiderio, possa indicare la strada verso l’amore e una forma di vita sociale più ricca di possibilità.

Quando le certezze crollano, si può solo cercare tra le rovine la possibilità di un mondo diverso. Pensiamo a Cenerentola: la sua scarpina è il frammento privo di vita che parla della sua assenza, ma è anche l’oggetto carico di desiderio che rende possibile la sua ricerca.

In una situazione storica analoga – caratterizzata dalla precarietà esistenziale e dalla crisi del legame sociale – Bazar Elettrico è stato il tentativo di condividere un “momento surrealista” nella routine della vita quotidiana: per evocare la magia degli oggetti e tracciare, attraverso un processo di creazione collettiva, la mappa degli incontri possibili.

Persone di tutte le età ed estrazioni – da sole, in coppia oppure in piccoli gruppi – sono partite dalla catastrofe per rimettersi subito in gioco.

Non solo hanno giocato i bambini, ma tutti, come bambini, hanno smontato e rimontato la realtà, inventando connessioni sempre nuove, e producendo il fragile miracolo di un’espressione al tempo stesso soggettiva e collettiva del desiderio.

 

Ph.: Lucrezia Delle Acque

 

Ph.: Giuseppe Santoro

 

Sotto la guida degli studenti del liceo artistico, i partecipanti si sono emozionati guardando i giganteschi video di un ragazzo e una ragazza che si sarebbero persi o non si sarebbero mai incontrati.

 

Ph.: Giuseppe Santoro

 

Interagendo con questi video, si sono fatti toccare dalle loro vite, hanno cominciato a prendersene cura e sono andati così alla ricerca degli oggetti che avrebbero potuto farli incontrare.

 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio

 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio

 

Ph.: Lucrezia Delle Acque

 

Fotografati e stampati in diretta, gli oggetti selezionati hanno pian piano elettrizzato il bazar, componendo un vibrante ed eterogeneo montaggio di pensieri, ricordi, emozioni, storie reali o immaginate. Un Crazy Wall – simile a quelli su cui i detective svolgono le loro indagini – che però non è servito a scoprire il colpevole di un delitto, ma a inventare i percorsi possibili attraverso cui i due ragazzi avrebbero potuto incontrarsi.

 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio

 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio

 

Nei giorni dell’evento, lo Spazio Murat si è trasformato in una macchina desiderante: un formidabile intensificatore di “possibili”. Le centinaia di fogli, con le foto e i pensieri dei partecipanti, poggiati come farfalle sul muro dei desideri, sono state la concreta testimonianza, al tempo stesso fragile e carica di potenza, che un mondo diverso è possibile.

 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio

 

 

3. Un libro per continuare a incontrarsi e a giocare: la gaia scienza delle rovine.

 

L’evento ci ha lasciato un piccolo tesoro che ora, con il vostro aiuto, vorremmo trasformare in un libro: per custodire il fragile miracolo; per rivitalizzarlo con i partener del progetto; per condividerlo con chi non ha avuto l’occasione di partecipare all’esperienza. 

Questo slogan ha accompagnato la preparazione di Bazar elettrico in Action.

Ce lo siamo detti, ce lo siamo ripetuti ogni volta che ci siamo incontrati con gli studenti del liceo artistico e con i migranti ospiti dello Sprar di Bari.

Poi l’evento è arrivato. Ed eravamo pronti. Pronti a mettere il tempo fuori di sesto, a creare la lieve distorsione di un altrove. Pronti a condividere una piccola estasi nella vita quotidiana.

Pronti a partire da una catastrofe immaginaria, per metterci subito, concretamente, in viaggio verso il pianeta Possibile. Pronti anche ad affrontare le catastrofi reali, come quando una bomba d’acqua si è abbattuta sulla città inondando lo spazio in cui si svolgeva l’evento. 

Pronti a navigare, a farci mosaico e a salvarci. Insieme.

Viviamo in un mondo che, invece di annunciare il sol dell’avvenire, è capace solo di vendere la notte dell’avvenire.

Un film senza la parola fine, nel quale ogni catastrofe diventa l’occasione per annunciare la successiva, con tutto il corollario di paure, di chiusure identitarie, di pericolose promesse di un mondo ridotto a “casa nostra”.

 

 

No, un altro presente è possibile! Ecco cosa ha detto l’esperienza di Bazar elettrico e per questo vogliamo andare avanti. 

Il processo è l’evento, e cioè: se il processo ha preceduto l’evento, allora vuol dire che potrà anche scavalcarlo.

Con il vostro aiuto vorremmo provare a continuare il viaggio: a ricostruire il pianeta Possibile attraverso un libro nel quale, attraverso l’eterogeneità dei materiali, delle forme e dei linguaggi, pulsino ancora altri tempi e altri luoghi.

Per continuare a smontare e rimontare la realtà camminando come funamboli tra l’esperienza storica dei surrealisti e i problemi del presente.

Per incontrarci ancora e giocare insieme come bambini. Per continuare a riflettere sulle cose che facciamo mentre le stiamo facendo.

E alla fine, quando il libro sarà pubblicato, per fare finalmente la festa cui fummo costretti a rinunciare, a causa dell’allagamento dello spazio che avevamo trasformato in una straordinaria macchina desiderante.  

Un nuovo miracolo ci attende. Fragile e potente come i nostri desideri. Come un volo di farfalle poggiate sul muro delle nostre vite.

 

 

4. La storia del progetto: per chi volesse approfondire

 

La ricerca è un viaggio senza capo né coda. Comincia sempre “nel mezzo” e così procede. Ogni ricerca è un pezzo di strada all’interno di una più ampia ed eterogenea rete di percorsi che si sovrappongono, s’intersecano, si diramano, fuggendo in tutte le direzioni.

L’idea di Bazar Elettrico in Action – l’happening/installazione che ha avuto luogo a Bari dal 14 al 19 novembre 2017 – nasce dalla ricerca di Action30, culminata nel volume Bazar elettrico. Bataille, Warburg, Benjamin at Work (2017), con cui il collettivo ha inaugurato per le edizioni Lavieri una collana dedicata al “saggio grafico”.

 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio

 

Action30 è un gruppo di ricercatori e artisti, attivo in Italia e all’estero da oltre dieci anni, che indaga sulle “nuove forme” di razzismo e fascismo attraverso l’analogia con gli anni ’30 del secolo scorso, e sperimenta nuove forme ibride di trasmissione e condivisione della cultura.

Il collettivo cerca di collegare le sue pratiche con una riflessione che poi si traduce in nuove sperimentazioni e così di seguito.

Il filo conduttore di tali sperimentazioni è il tentativo di condividere cultura, sviluppando una tensione tra gli archivi culturali e l’attualità, e usando la finzione o il gioco come funambolica passerella attraverso cui “sincronizzare” il passato con i problemi del presente. 

La scommessa del collettivo è, in fondo, quella di riuscire a tenere insieme l’autonomia dei percorsi di ricerca e l’urgente desiderio di condividerli con la gente. 

L’esperienza realizzata per la prima volta a Bari è stata il punto in cui due corsi d’acqua sono confluiti l’uno nell’altro formando un’unica corrente.

Il primo affluente è una ricerca di carattere “ecosistemico”.

Sappiamo che la diversità è la condizione che presiede allo sviluppo della vita naturale, ma spesso dimentichiamo che questo vale anche per la cultura: per lo sviluppo del pensiero, della creatività, delle forme di vita umane e sociali.

Di qui l’interesse del collettivo per alcune macchine di ricerca, riscoperte nell’archivio culturale, e che potrebbero essere “remixate” per metterle in sintonia con il presente. Le macchine di Bataille, Warburg e Banjamin sono banchi di montaggio ecosistemici: sospese le gerarchie e abbattuti gli steccati disciplinari, il tavolo da lavoro si riempie di una molteplicità di materiali eterogenei e una serie di montaggi inediti diventa possibile. Sono sistemi di ricerca basati sull’eterogeneità e che sprigionano quell’energia “differenziale” necessaria perché una cultura sia viva, vitale. Bazar elettrici che accendono il pensiero e la creatività.

 

 

Tutto questo ha un immediato risvolto “politico”, nel senso tali macchine di ricerca invitano a considerare in modo ecosistemico anche le forme di vita umane e sociali. Basti pensare che Warburg, lo studioso del Rinascimento che ha rivoluzionato l’approccio alla storia dell’arte, concepiva la cultura come una sorta di “cinema” della migrazione geografica e storica delle immagini. Non c’è cultura senza migrazioni, e le migrazioni sono un intensificatore di eterogeneità che vivifica in permanenza le culture.

Viviamo in un mondo in cui l’eterogeneo trionfa, come dimostra la banale esperienza di navigare sul web. Tuttavia, attraverso i flussi del mainstream – globalizzazione, gentrificazione, trasformazione della realtà in reality – l’eterogeneo è costantemente frullato e trasformato in omogeneo. Le “tendenze principali” sono implacabili distruttrici di ecosistemi eterogenei: dalla forma di vita di una tribù amazzonica o di un quartiere popolare, alle forme di pensiero critico e creativo. Così il terreno s’inaridisce e la cultura deperisce. Perciò bisogna provare a far girare il frullatore al contrario; a ottenere dall’omogeneo l’eterogeneo; a smontare e rimontare incessantemente i flussi del mainstream.

Fare cultura, oggi, significa in primo luogo praticare degli abicì culturali: per costruire nuove “mappe sinaptiche”; per inventare altre connessioni con noi stessi, con gli altri, con la realtà, con il mondo.

Il secondo affluente è la creazione di nuovi format per la “condivisione della cultura”.

In questi anni, il collettivo Action30 ha sperimentato dei format “ibridi” finalizzati, non a produrre consenso, ma a condividere con la gente percorsi analitici, problemi, domande: saggi-grafici, performance-dibattito, saggi-spettacolo.

A un certo punto questi tentativi non sono parsi soddisfacenti: non tanto sul piano delle proposte culturali, quanto su quello della “partecipazione” della gente ai percorsi proposti. La cultura non è forse “lavoro” condiviso? Si può condividere cultura senza l’effettiva partecipazione degli “altri”?

Nonostante le migliori intenzione, il libro, la performance e lo spettacolo sono dispositivi “chiusi”: da un lato ci sono gli autori e gli attori, dall’altro i lettori e gli spettatori.

Per la prima volta, con Bazar elettrico in Action, il collettivo ha fatto esplodere la “scena”: dapprima condividendo il progetto con gli studenti del liceo artistico “Pascali-De Nittis” e con gli ospiti minori e adulti dello Sprar di Bari; in seguito facendo partecipare centinaia di persone a un gioco surrealista con gli oggetti che era anche, e al tempo stesso, un’esperienza ecosistemica sulla precarietà esistenziale e sulla crisi del legame sociale. 

 

Ph.: Giuseppe Santoro

 

In tal modo, la ricerca del collettivo ha potuto essere condivisa, producendo una dinamica partecipata e una creazione collettiva. Ed è su questa strada che intendiamo proseguire: attraverso una pubblicazione che, non solo restituisca l’esperienza, ma diventi anche l’occasione per continuare a incontrarsi, a riflettere e a creare, in uno stile plurale e cooperativo.

 

 

 

 

Cos'altro puoi fare

Oltre a contribuire al crowdfunding, partecipa attivamente seguendoci sui nostri canali e condividendo la campagna per la pubblicazione del volume "La gaia scienza delle rovine".

Dopo la catastrofe della I Guerra mondiale, pressati dalla crisi economica e dal fascismo che si diffonde in Europa, i surrealisti si aggirano in trance alla ricerca di oggetti, segnali, strani indizi: tutto quello che, facendo vibrare il loro desiderio, possa indicare la strada verso l’amore e una forma di vita sociale più ricca di possibilità.
Quando le certezze crollano, si può solo cercare tra le rovine la possibilità di un mondo diverso. Pensiamo a Cenerentola: la sua scarpina è il frammento privo di vita che parla della sua assenza, ma è anche l’oggetto carico di desiderio che rende possibile la sua ricerca.
In una situazione storica analoga – caratterizzata dalla precarietà esistenziale e dalla crisi del legame sociale – Bazar Elettrico è stato il tentativo di condividere un “momento surrealista” nella routine della vita quotidiana: per evocare la magia degli oggetti e tracciare, attraverso un processo di creazione collettiva, la mappa degli incontri possibili.
Persone di tutte le età ed estrazioni – da sole, in coppia oppure in piccoli gruppi – sono partite dalla catastrofe per rimettersi subito in gioco.
Non solo hanno giocato i bambini, ma tutti, come bambini, hanno smontato e rimontato la realtà, inventando connessioni sempre nuove, e producendo il fragile miracolo di un’espressione al tempo stesso soggettiva e collettiva del desiderio.
 

Ph.: Lucrezia Delle Acque
 

Ph.: Giuseppe Santoro
 
Sotto la guida degli studenti del liceo artistico, i partecipanti si sono emozionati guardando i giganteschi video di un ragazzo e una ragazza che si sarebbero persi o non si sarebbero mai incontrati.
 

Ph.: Giuseppe Santoro
 
Interagendo con questi video, si sono fatti toccare dalle loro vite, hanno cominciato a prendersene cura e sono andati così alla ricerca degli oggetti che avrebbero potuto farli incontrare.
 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio
 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio
 

Ph.: Lucrezia Delle Acque
 
Fotografati e stampati in diretta, gli oggetti selezionati hanno pian piano elettrizzato il bazar, componendo un vibrante ed eterogeneo montaggio di pensieri, ricordi, emozioni, storie reali o immaginate. Un Crazy Wall – simile a quelli su cui i detective svolgono le loro indagini – che però non è servito a scoprire il colpevole di un delitto, ma a inventare i percorsi possibili attraverso cui i due ragazzi avrebbero potuto incontrarsi.
 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio
 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio
 
Nei giorni dell’evento, lo Spazio Murat si è trasformato in una macchina desiderante: un formidabile intensificatore di “possibili”. Le centinaia di fogli, con le foto e i pensieri dei partecipanti, poggiati come farfalle sul muro dei desideri, sono state la concreta testimonianza, al tempo stesso fragile e carica di potenza, che un mondo diverso è possibile.
 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio
 
 
3. Un libro per continuare a incontrarsi e a giocare: la gaia scienza delle rovine.
 
L’evento ci ha lasciato un piccolo tesoro che ora, con il vostro aiuto, vorremmo trasformare in un libro: per custodire il fragile miracolo; per rivitalizzarlo con i partener del progetto; per condividerlo con chi non ha avuto l’occasione di partecipare all’esperienza. 

Questo slogan ha accompagnato la preparazione di Bazar elettrico in Action.
Ce lo siamo detti, ce lo siamo ripetuti ogni volta che ci siamo incontrati con gli studenti del liceo artistico e con i migranti ospiti dello Sprar di Bari.
Poi l’evento è arrivato. Ed eravamo pronti. Pronti a mettere il tempo fuori di sesto, a creare la lieve distorsione di un altrove. Pronti a condividere una piccola estasi nella vita quotidiana.
Pronti a partire da una catastrofe immaginaria, per metterci subito, concretamente, in viaggio verso il pianeta Possibile. Pronti anche ad affrontare le catastrofi reali, come quando una bomba d’acqua si è abbattuta sulla città inondando lo spazio in cui si svolgeva l’evento. 
Pronti a navigare, a farci mosaico e a salvarci. Insieme.
Viviamo in un mondo che, invece di annunciare il sol dell’avvenire, è capace solo di vendere la notte dell’avvenire.
Un film senza la parola fine, nel quale ogni catastrofe diventa l’occasione per annunciare la successiva, con tutto il corollario di paure, di chiusure identitarie, di pericolose promesse di un mondo ridotto a “casa nostra”.
 

 
No, un altro presente è possibile! Ecco cosa ha detto l’esperienza di Bazar elettrico e per questo vogliamo andare avanti. 
Il processo è l’evento, e cioè: se il processo ha preceduto l’evento, allora vuol dire che potrà anche scavalcarlo.
Con il vostro aiuto vorremmo provare a continuare il viaggio: a ricostruire il pianeta Possibile attraverso un libro nel quale, attraverso l’eterogeneità dei materiali, delle forme e dei linguaggi, pulsino ancora altri tempi e altri luoghi.

Per continuare a smontare e rimontare la realtà camminando come funamboli tra l’esperienza storica dei surrealisti e i problemi del presente.
Per incontrarci ancora e giocare insieme come bambini. Per continuare a riflettere sulle cose che facciamo mentre le stiamo facendo.
E alla fine, quando il libro sarà pubblicato, per fare finalmente la festa cui fummo costretti a rinunciare, a causa dell’allagamento dello spazio che avevamo trasformato in una straordinaria macchina desiderante.  
Un nuovo miracolo ci attende. Fragile e potente come i nostri desideri. Come un volo di farfalle poggiate sul muro delle nostre vite.
 
 
4. La storia del progetto: per chi volesse approfondire
 
La ricerca è un viaggio senza capo né coda. Comincia sempre “nel mezzo” e così procede. Ogni ricerca è un pezzo di strada all’interno di una più ampia ed eterogenea rete di percorsi che si sovrappongono, s’intersecano, si diramano, fuggendo in tutte le direzioni.
L’idea di Bazar Elettrico in Action – l’happening/installazione che ha avuto luogo a Bari dal 14 al 19 novembre 2017 – nasce dalla ricerca di Action30, culminata nel volume Bazar elettrico. Bataille, Warburg, Benjamin at Work (2017), con cui il collettivo ha inaugurato per le edizioni Lavieri una collana dedicata al “saggio grafico”.
 

Ph.: Arnaldo Di Vittorio
 
Action30 è un gruppo di ricercatori e artisti, attivo in Italia e all’estero da oltre dieci anni, che indaga sulle “nuove forme” di razzismo e fascismo attraverso l’analogia con gli anni ’30 del secolo scorso, e sperimenta nuove forme ibride di trasmissione e condivisione della cultura.
Il collettivo cerca di collegare le sue pratiche con una riflessione che poi si traduce in nuove sperimentazioni e così di seguito.
Il filo conduttore di tali sperimentazioni è il tentativo di condividere cultura, sviluppando una tensione tra gli archivi culturali e l’attualità, e usando la finzione o il gioco come funambolica passerella attraverso cui “sincronizzare” il passato con i problemi del presente. 
La scommessa del collettivo è, in fondo, quella di riuscire a tenere insieme l’autonomia dei percorsi di ricerca e l’urgente desiderio di condividerli con la gente. 
L’esperienza realizzata per la prima volta a Bari è stata il punto in cui due corsi d’acqua sono confluiti l’uno nell’altro formando un’unica corrente.
Il primo affluente è una ricerca di carattere “ecosistemico”.
Sappiamo che la diversità è la condizione che presiede allo sviluppo della vita naturale, ma spesso dimentichiamo che questo vale anche per la cultura: per lo sviluppo del pensiero, della creatività, delle forme di vita umane e sociali.
Di qui l’interesse del collettivo per alcune macchine di ricerca, riscoperte nell’archivio culturale, e che potrebbero essere “remixate” per metterle in sintonia con il presente. Le macchine di Bataille, Warburg e Banjamin sono banchi di montaggio ecosistemici: sospese le gerarchie e abbattuti gli steccati disciplinari, il tavolo da lavoro si riempie di una molteplicità di materiali eterogenei e una serie di montaggi inediti diventa possibile. Sono sistemi di ricerca basati sull’eterogeneità e che sprigionano quell’energia “differenziale” necessaria perché una cultura sia viva, vitale. Bazar elettrici che accendono il pensiero e la creatività.
 

 
Tutto questo ha un immediato risvolto “politico”, nel senso tali macchine di ricerca invitano a considerare in modo ecosistemico anche le forme di vita umane e sociali. Basti pensare che Warburg, lo studioso del Rinascimento che ha rivoluzionato l’approccio alla storia dell’arte, concepiva la cultura come una sorta di “cinema” della migrazione geografica e storica delle immagini. Non c’è cultura senza migrazioni, e le migrazioni sono un intensificatore di eterogeneità che vivifica in permanenza le culture.
Viviamo in un mondo in cui l’eterogeneo trionfa, come dimostra la banale esperienza di navigare sul web. Tuttavia, attraverso i flussi del mainstream – globalizzazione, gentrificazione, trasformazione della realtà in reality – l’eterogeneo è costantemente frullato e trasformato in omogeneo. Le “tendenze principali” sono implacabili distruttrici di ecosistemi eterogenei: dalla forma di vita di una tribù amazzonica o di un quartiere popolare, alle forme di pensiero critico e creativo. Così il terreno s’inaridisce e la cultura deperisce. Perciò bisogna provare a far girare il frullatore al contrario; a ottenere dall’omogeneo l’eterogeneo; a smontare e rimontare incessantemente i flussi del mainstream.
Fare cultura, oggi, significa in primo luogo praticare degli abicì culturali: per costruire nuove “mappe sinaptiche”; per inventare altre connessioni con noi stessi, con gli altri, con la realtà, con il mondo.
Il secondo affluente è la creazione di nuovi format per la “condivisione della cultura”.
In questi anni, il collettivo Action30 ha sperimentato dei format “ibridi” finalizzati, non a produrre consenso, ma a condividere con la gente percorsi analitici, problemi, domande: saggi-grafici, performance-dibattito, saggi-spettacolo.
A un certo punto questi tentativi non sono parsi soddisfacenti: non tanto sul piano delle proposte culturali, quanto su quello della “partecipazione” della gente ai percorsi proposti. La cultura non è forse “lavoro” condiviso? Si può condividere cultura senza l’effettiva partecipazione degli “altri”?
Nonostante le migliori intenzione, il libro, la performance e lo spettacolo sono dispositivi “chiusi”: da un lato ci sono gli autori e gli attori, dall’altro i lettori e gli spettatori.
Per la prima volta, con Bazar elettrico in Action, il collettivo ha fatto esplodere la “scena”: dapprima condividendo il progetto con gli studenti del liceo artistico “Pascali-De Nittis” e con gli ospiti minori e adulti dello Sprar di Bari; in seguito facendo partecipare centinaia di persone a un gioco surrealista con gli oggetti che era anche, e al tempo stesso, un’esperienza ecosistemica sulla precarietà esistenziale e sulla crisi del legame sociale. 
 

Ph.: Giuseppe Santoro
 
In tal modo, la ricerca del collettivo ha potuto essere condivisa, producendo una dinamica partecipata e una creazione collettiva. Ed è su questa strada che intendiamo proseguire: attraverso una pubblicazione che, non solo restituisca l’esperienza, ma diventi anche l’occasione per continuare a incontrarsi, a riflettere e a creare, in uno stile plurale e cooperativo.
 

 
 
 
Cos'altro puoi fareOltre a contribuire al crowdfunding, partecipa attivamente seguendoci sui nostri canali e condividendo la campagna per la pubblicazione del volume "La gaia scienza delle rovine".

story:
We, ‘GarageArt’, are an independent Cultural Space and art café in Irbid, Jordan, that is run by a network of artists and art activists of the association ‘MedeArts’  in Irbid. We have a passion for arts and culture, and believe in the values of dialogue, acceptance and respect. ‘GarageArt’, is open to everyone at all times and provides its members and the local community with a Safe Space to gather, exchange and create. As a result of Covid-19 and other obstacles faced, we were not able to generate enough money to cover our rent and are now at risk of losing our space. Therefore, we have decided to launch this campaign so that with your support, we will be able to continue our work and save this space for our community.

FYI: As a team member of GarageArt I am launching this campaign in representation as an individual, since it is almost impossible for Nonprofits based in Jordan to do so. 

 

Where your money goes: 

To keep our space open, we would mainly need help to cover the rent as we would be able to cover the minor expenses of running costs and staff compensations through the income we were and are still able to generate with our café and the activities we host. Rents in Jordan are often paid for 6 months in advance, which in our case amounts to 3000 EUR (2986.10 exactly). Covering this amount would enable us to bridge the current difficult times until we are able to generate sufficient income again. 

 

Why GarageArt? 

Establishing and maintaining ‘GarageArt’ for young people and artists from our communities was and is our heartfelt desire, as many of these young people suffer from non-acceptance in their own society with no place to go.

To address that, we have been working hard over the past years to operate a space where local youth and local artists can do what they love, feel empowered, create and connect with likeminded people. Growing up as artists in Irbid ourselves and having faced many obstacles, we know how important it is to have a space like this. To remain independent, we have set-up a self-sustaining economic system, by which we generate income through our café space and the different cultural events we host. However, Covid-19 and a recent smear campaign against us by social media and individuals made it impossible to generate sufficient means to keep our doors open. 

Irbid is a rather conservative place in which music, theatre and other forms of arts may already be considered morally unacceptable. In this particular case, a regular concert attended by women and men together was already enough to spark outrage amongst some individuals, who actively went against us. We were asked to cancel events, faced threats that our space would be closed and heard from customers that they were prevented by their families from coming. Having experienced that, for us it is now more important than ever to fight these tendencies by promoting openness and tolerance and maintaining a space in which young people can feel safe and accepted, exchange and be involved in arts and culture. 

 

What we have achieved over the past two years

‘GarageArt’ is a vibrant place hosting many different community projects. Next to having our doors open for everyone to meet we are offering all kinds of art workshops and host film screenings, theatre and storytelling performances, as well as music performances of various genres. In addition to that, we organize various discussions close to the heart of our Youth like questions about ‘identity’ and facilitate meetings with local decision makers to promote the art and cultural scene in our city and ensure that the voices of our young artists and youth are heard. 

Despite Covid-19 and while maintaining strict safety measures, we were able to host more than 100 activities in our space over the past 12 months. Some of the highlights were:

  • 26/08/2020: Team Painting Event for youth from Jordan Valley and Irbid
  • 29-30/09/2020: Songwriting Workshop wit Ahmed Farah
  • 26-27/10/2020: Sudanese Film Days supported by Goethe Institute Amman
  • 31/10/2020: ‘Tea Talk’ about Mental Health
  • 12/12/2020: All-Women Talk with Feminist Collective ‘Takatoat’
  • 05-06/01/2021: Karama Human Rights Film Festival 11 - Irbid Outreach
  • 24/01/2021: Theatre Play ‘A Lockdown-Night Dream’ directed by Hakim Harb
  • 16/02/2021: Melosika Band Performance and Discussion
  • 27/02/2021: Collective Art Workshop and Gallery
  • 08/03/2021: International Women’s Day with Artists Heba Nabulsi
  • 10-11/04/2021: Mask Making Workshop with Artists Yasmeen Kurdi
  • 12-14/06/2021: Pottery and Mosaic Workshops
 

Risks & Challenges

Given that we are working in the field of arts and culture in a very conservative community there is always the challenge of building and maintaining trust. Since the start of GarageArt we have involved our local community and worked closely together as for many, the kind of cultural activities we offer is new.  Throughout the two years we managed to build trust and create a Safe Space frequently visited and loved by many young people and families from Irbid as well as artists and cultural actors from Jordan and beyond. Despite that, there are still individuals in our community who actively work against us. The recent smear campaign with false accusations and defamations which was shared widely on social media put our space at risk. At the same time, the support and positive affirmations we received from our networks and friends gave us courage and showed us how immensely important it is not to give up. 

However, given the economically difficult situation we are already facing as a result of Covid-19, it is currently not possible for us to cover our rent. Even though we are aware that the Covid-19 related restrictions will continue in one way or the other during the upcoming months, we are certain that once we can overcome the hard times we are currently facing, we will be able to re-establish our self-sustainability, generate enough money through our Café and events and be able to continue independently. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every amount is helpful! If you can’t donate yourself it would be great if you could share this call with people you know. However, please share it only privately and don’t publish it online as the situation we are currently facing is very sensitive given the smear campaign against us. 

Thank you so much for standing with us and for supporting youth and the artist community in Irbid!

story:
About AVIV Festival

The Israeli Artists Project (IAP) is proud to present our inaugural AVIV Festival, a celebration of Israeli arts and culture.

AVIV Festival is the first month-long event of its kind.

The Festival will include over a dozen unique activities with over 30 individual performances, showcasing a variety of visual and performing arts.

The Festival will feature the award-winning play, "Best Friends," by Israeli playwright Anat Gov, presented in both Hebrew and English. Additionally, there will be an array of theatrical and musical performances by local Israeli artists, a comedy night, an art exhibition, a play for kids and more!

The Festival will take place throughout the month of May, co-presented by The Theater at 14th Street Y.

Tickets will be available for purchase via the 14th Street Y's website. [Stay tuned for details.]

Contact us at info@israeliartistsproject.org for group rates, sponsorship opportunities and volunteer roles.

#AVIVFestival2020

 

We're Almost There!!!

  • Without the last $20,000 we need to raise from donors, friends and family, we will not be able to host this incredible inaugural event.

  • Your donation to our Indiegogo campaign literally helps us turn the lights on.
     
  • This will be the most exciting Israeli cultural event in NYC of the year! Engage with local and international talent and gain special access with VIP passes and promotional opportunities.
     
  • AVIV Festival connects generations and communities and brings the light and love of Israel and Israeli culture right here to New York.
     
  • Every dollar counts towards this large undertaking. IAP is currently in its second production season on a shoestring budget. We have big dreams to increase our programming and hope to create an annual attraction for years to come, starting with this year's dynamic AVIV Festival.
     
  • For organizations, companies, or foundations who wish to contribute as an official Sponsor of AVIV Festival, please contact us at info@israeliartistsproject.org. Opportunities include "co-presenting" events, strategic logo placement, ads, in-kind donations and more.

 

 

About Israeli Artists Project

Israeli Artists Project promotes and presents Israeli music, theater and art. IAP (pronounced “yap”) is a community-oriented non-profit organization that provides a stage for local Israeli artists as well as as opportunities for Americans and Israelis to experience Israeli culture together beyond the lenses of politics and religion.

IAP is fiscally sponsored by America-Israel Cultural Foundation. 

In our first year alone, we entertained thousands of audience members and incorporated dozens of Israeli performers and visual artists into our repertoire. 

We have partnered on events with America-Israeli Cultural Foundation (AICF), Israeli American Council (IAC), HOMEIS and JCCs, Ys, Israeli House, synagogues, schools and other organizations down the East Coast from New York to Florida. We are constantly reaching out to additional groups to share our stages and seats and look forward to building friendship across North America around our shared love of Israeli culture.

Our community of Jewish Americans and Israelis, as well as those who appreciate our art and culture grows with each production we host.

In our first year alone, we entertained thousands of audience members and incorporated dozens of Israeli performers and visual artists into our repertoire. 
We have partnered on events with America-Israeli Cultural Foundation (AICF), Israeli American Council (IAC), HOMEIS and JCCs, Ys, Israeli House, synagogues, schools and other organizations down the East Coast from New York to Florida. We are constantly reaching out to additional groups to share our stages and seats and look forward to building friendship across North America around our shared love of Israeli culture.Our community of Jewish Americans and Israelis, as well as those who appreciate our art and culture grows with each production we host.

story:
What The 10K Project? 

In his best-selling book Outliers, award-winning author (and Canadian) Malcolm Gladwell famously wrote that it takes roughly 10,000 hours of practice to achieve mastery in a field. 

The 10K Project is a 10,000 mile/hour/blood, sweat & tears journey to establish Toronto's acting community as #1 in the world.  Through a variety of initiatives including workshops, competitions, live performance, and film/web and tv projects, we hope to create the necessary platform for Toronto actors to achieve their dreams. It's all about the four C's: Creation, Collaboration, Competition and Community. 

Below are just a few of the initiatives we hope to launch. 

 

Dream Scenes 

If you’re an actor then your success depends on showcasing your work. Most actors we encounter have the same issues:

  • I need material for my demo reel.
  • I need a demo reel to get an agent.
  • I need an agent to get auditions. 
  • I need auditions to land a gig. 
  • I’ve been trying to audition for student films or non union gigs OR
  • I was cast in a student film or non union gig but don’t have any screen time.
  • I just did a thing but won’t get footage for 6 months to a year.
  • I did this thing but the Director died in a freak accident and in his last will he requested that the footage be buried with him. 
  • I have some footage but it’s not great OR
  • I've grown artistically (aka I lost weight)
  • I need a way to show that I can play a deranged ex con with a chip on their shoulder. 
  • I literally have no friends and trying to do something myself is like telling me to swim to China. 

Dream Scenes was created to give actors a low budget platform to collaborate with writers, directors and producers in developing compelling and original content. The goal is create work that truly represents you as an artist, while developing your production and writing skills.

In just over a year we've written, shot and edited over 50 Dream Scenes!

 

Pilot Season

"A television pilot is a standalone episode of a series that is meant to be the testing ground to gauge whether a series will be successful." - I googled that sh%t

Pilot Season is content incubator and a friendly competition (cause we're Canadians) where we produce a variety of Pilot episodes for an innovative new series. The people decide which one will be developed into a full series. There are NO losers here, just people who didn't win. The top 3 projects get pitched to the lovely people at Bell Fibe TV 1. 

 

 

The Docu-Series

"The Series" is an untitled docu-series that explores our journey in developing Toronto actors and creating a legitimate Star System here in Toronto. Experience this dynamic and exciting art form through the lens of it's greatest protagonists. We will select 10-12 brilliant actors to participate in this incubator and provide them with  mentors, resources and the tools to succeed. This series will air on Bell FIBE TV in  2017. 

 

What Do We Need?

While most of our projects have been simple, low budget, with quick turnaround and minimal post production (still dope AF), we're looking to take things to the NEXT LEVEL in 2017. Our goal is to invest in equipment, cast, crew, permits, rentals, lighting, sound, craft services and post production are all integral in taking this city to the top (aka #1 Film/TV/ Theatre Industry).  

 

What You Get (aka The Perks)

We have some amazing perks lined up for our supporters! 

Check out the links and pick one...pick em all! 

 

The Impact 

Ultimately we hope to create a more viable and vibrant Canadian film and television industry that competes internationally. My philosophy is that with frequent opportunities to experiment and create, our good work will become our worst and our best will be game changing. This means creating a consistent and supportive environment where ideas can flourish and come to life. The 10K project means more opportunities for work and a platform for actors to create content and develop projects for themselves and others in the community. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Our greatest obstacle is APATHY. Individuals who don't believe in the potential our community or that our city can truly be the best in the world.  Over the past five years Toronto has become one of the major talent hubs for musicians, athletes and now it's time for us storytellers to realize our full potential.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have a lot of cash laying around, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Share this campaign and tell friends about this project
  • Volunteer a helping hand in one of our productions
  • Yell at lazy people. Light a fire under their a$$

And that's all there is to it.

story:
About

Chrissa Amuah (Designer), and Alice Asafu-Adjaye (Architect), both of dual Ghanaian-British nationality, and practicing in London and Accra respectively, combine their insights and perspectives on art and design to represent Ghana at the London Design Biennale 2021, at Somerset House, London. Originally set to take place in September last year, the biennale has been rescheduled to 1 - 31 June this year, due to the pandemic.

The Ghana pavilion, titled Amplify, explores the conversation between Ghana and two of its former colonial rulers, Britain and Denmark, over four centuries.

In response to the exhibition theme of ‘Resonance’, Amplify focuses on the ‘what ifs’ and ‘maybes,’ should contact have been a balanced cultural interchange of ideas and trade. Amplify is a concept study that demonstrates how mutual growth and development benefits all, in contrast to a period when Europeans were developing societies with art and culture at their core, at the expense of their colonies – an example of which is Somerset House.

A site specific concept, the architecture and 450 year history of Somerset House, provide the perfect foil for a project that explores a rich Ghanaian cultural tapestry.

Amplify will explore and manipulate; materials, space, light and textures, provoking an evolution of attitudes and ideology. And furthermore, it will reveal an equilibrium of environmental and cultural sensitivity that resonates with the 21st century.

This year's London Design Biennale will coincide with the G7's 47th summit in London.

 

Thank You For Your Consideration

To everyone that has donated, encouraged, endorsed, supported and followed, we’d like to say a massive THANK YOU!!!

While we are some way away from our fundraising target, we are still confident in our plans to participate and are prepared to adjust our design to our final budget. As the ONLY sub-Saharan participant it is not an option for us to withdraw having come so far.

We look forward to your continued support.

For those that are yet to donate, we are so close to the finishing line and ask for your help to get us there. Your support will contribute to a public facing pavilion that not only makes Africans and people of African descent proud, but that will speak to our shared humanity and a desire for a future that nods to cultural and societal exchanges that are both celebrations and tools of learning.

story:
The HomeComputerMuseum

The HomeComputerMuseum is a non-profit organization in the Netherlands (Dutch: Culturele ANBI-status, US: 501(c)(3) )

Our Mission:

Preserve and share the history of the home computer for and with current and future generations.

We achieve this by

1 - 500m2 Interactive museum in the city of Helmond, in the Brainport Region in central Benelux. Providing not only working and playable computers from 1975 - 2005 but also an atmosphere from the era the computer was created. Sharing information about computers and background stories via our website and our tour, educate the history of the computer for schools and give nostalgic feelings to the visitors to remember their first computer.

2 - Providing repairs for both old and new computers and selling (retro)computers and retro computer parts for a fair price.

3 - Providing care for people with autism and otherwise challenged people with expanding their social and technical skills by giving them a safe, stress-free and friendly work space and discover new possibilities for them to eventually return to a normal work environment.

4 - Renting out retro computers for movies, series, commercials and any other place that needs a working and good looking retro computer.

What We Need

The HomeComputerMuseum houses an unique collections of hundreds of computers and even more stories about these computers. Stories you can't find on the internet (yet), stories told by directors, managers, employees and users of all these computers. Stories we like to share to the world and we've choosen the live stream to do so. Despite us having the material for it and that's where IndieGoGo came along!

We've set a few goals.

  • When we reach €125: We'll simply stream using our smartphone. No chat and quality is, well, ok-ish? 
  • When we reach the goal of €350 we'll rent a professional camera and cameraman filming us in Full HD-resolution. Also a team of our volunteers will be on the chat to answer the questions (and if you're lucky, the answer will be on video)
  • When we reach €1000, we're going to invest in better light and better atmosphere in the museum. The video will be even better.
  • For €2500, we'll buy our own streaming gear and make more videos of us repairing or testing (old) computers.
  • For €5000, we'll do the same as for the €2500, but this gives us major support to continue the museum and improve it even more!
  • For €12500, we'll do everything above and create an app to visit the museum 24x7. It will be for Android and Apple and will give all the background information.
  • Ultimate goal: €25000. This will give us a huge financial boost to improve the whole museum and experience.  We will create a mobile app for Apple and Android with the whole tour integrated, so you can visit 24x7! Every penny left will be invested in improving the museum to make sure we will become the biggest and most amazing one (I think we already are, but hey... ;-) )

What You Get aka Perks

Next to the live streaming tour, which is included in all perks, we will offer a few items more. We have a neat T-shirt

Or an awesome sticker that they've promised will keep it's color for at least 2 years (size is a little over a 3,5" disk).

Since we hope that we have a lot of viewers of this tour, we like to offer companies to put their logo in the stream and possibly future streams/videos. This way, as a company, you can reach the audience quickly and you're supporting a real museum. Seems like a win-win to me :)

The Impact

For even the smallest amount, you'll get to see the unique museum and hear the amazing stories we have, from the comfort of your own home (or office). You don't need to travel to Helmond (near Eindhoven) and find a place to sleep, you can just watch.

Of course you can read a lot of information on the Internet, but to actually see it and ask live questions about it, is so much better. 

I'm not asking to save the museum or help us open a museum. It's already there! We offer you to get the full tour as you are in the actual museum and this time, you can eat and drink whatever you like. 

Yes, if we have more money, the money will flow into the further existence of the museum. We need quite some improvements and we like to be able to invest.

Risks & Challenges

This is not a "we can't make it if we don't have the funds"-campaign. Even if we don't make the ultimate goal, we still continue to exist as a museum. If we don't make the smallest goal of €125, well, there won't be a livestream and you should actually get up and come over to Helmond to visit the museum in person. However, all the money received from this campaign will be put to good use in the museum. We won't buy a bunch of beer and get drunk, but it will be invested.

  • The minimum is €125, but we can really show it in the best possible way at the €1000-mark.
  • The €2500 gives us our own gear (instead of renting it), meaning we can continue making videos in a professional way.
  • Every euro above €2500 will be invested in the museum. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can't contribute with money, but still want to help. 

  • Spread the word using the share buttons! 
  • Ask your friend(s) to chip in and watch together, it'll be fun! 
  • If you're in the general area of Eindhoven, feel free to actually visit the museum. It is a great trip down memory lane.

story:
Short Summary

Lukeko Gaun, a village for arts and farming, is the dream center of International Center for Social Theater Nepal, where we aspire to bring creative people together to create a better world for everyone.

In the far corner of Lalitpur district near Kathmandu Valley, we're currently building a community center which will be useful for both the guests and neighbors of village. Our community center is a hub for all theater practitioners, yoga and meditation lovers, and all kinds of artists to meet, create and be one with nature. The center envisions forming a community of people to celebrate love all around and help regain peace, love and happiness in the world. People of the center become the change makers of the society.

Additionally, at the community center, we aspire to empower the local youths and women by providing them various training and workshops. Many theater workshops as well as residencies are being planned to be conducted in the community center which will ultimately provide job opportunities to the locals.

We're a small group of people who are passionate about theater and arts, so we're hopeful that the kind hearts of the world will work together with us to reach our goal of making an art community.

What We Need & What You Get

At the moment, in order to build our community center, we're making do with the resources locally available to us and have also started a goat farm to sustain ourselves. But we need your support to help us complete the construction of the community center.

Our planned structure includes building:
1. A community hall for events like training, workshop, yoga, meditation and so on,
2. A library that can be used by both the residents and the locals,
3. A hostel for residencies and for volunteer accommodation, along with a kitchen and few washrooms,
4. A few small cottages inside the forest for those seeking solace and inspiration in nature,

5. An eco-friendly tree-house reading space,

6. A permaculture farm,

7. And planting 200 trees in the Lukeko Gaun premises.

What do the donors get from helping us?
With a common dream of bringing the world together, while you help us by donating, we help you by delivering your love and concern to the society without requiring you to spare time from your busy schedule. We appreciate donations as small as $10 because we know you care and for that we cannot give you anything except love and blessings. Additionally, if you solely or in partnership sponsor any of our proposed buildings, we assure you that the building will be named after you. After all, everyone needs to know the name of the person behind the kind gesture. And if some day you plan to visit us, you will get to enjoy the love and affection of our local neighbors too.

The Impact

Through our center, we hope to have a larger impact in to bringing oneness in the world. Some of the other impacts include:

  • A hub for artists, theater practitioners, yogis and creators from all around the globe
  • Working space for creative individuals and groups
  • A center for yoga and meditation that everyone can benefit from
  • Exchange of culture as well as ideas between the global and the local communities
  • Employment opportunities to the locals along with various training and workshops
  • Market for locally farmed produces

Risks & Challenges

As ours is an ambitious project, we might have to face a few challenges like in-coordination of the locals or the lack to visiting residents who can add value to the community. We, however, take these challenges and motivation and work harder everyday to set things right.

We, as of now, have cordial relationship with all our neighbors, and with our friendly ways, we plan on keeping situations under control. As far as the visiting residents are concerned, we are sure that all our fellow artist friends and the ones who've visited us personally will help us spread the word around.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some of you may be unable to help us financially but you can still help us by:

  • Volunteering directly at our community center and farm.
  • Getting the word out and spreading the news of our campaign.
  • Sharing our campaign by using Indiegogo share tools!

Love and Gratitude!

story:
Venus Venue - et event for mangfoldighed i Nordjylland.

Venus Venue er et initiativ, som er taget af 5 nordjyske kvinder - som alle har det til fælles, at vi ønsker et større fokus på kropspositivisme, LGBT+-miljøer og ligestilling i Nordjylland. 

Ved at iværksætte et gratis event, hvor der sættes fokus på emner som tykfobi, kønsnormer, diversitet, selvkærlighed og meget mere - gennem workshops, debat, oplæg og musik - ønsker vi at sætte et positivt aftryk i Nordjylland.

Vi synes, at alle har ret til at være stolte over hvem de er, hvordan de ser ud og hvordan de ønsker at udtrykke sig. Vi vil gerne være med til at give mere albuerum til mangfoldigheden og sætte samtaler i gang om diversitet og selvkærlighed. 

2021 er det første år, hvor eventet skal afholdes. Eventet planlægges at blive afholdt en gang om året fremover. I år finder det sted i HUSET, Aalborg - lørdag d. 23. oktober.

 

Hvad vi har brug for og hvad du får ud af at støtte os:

Vores event bliver båret af frivillig arbejdskraft. Arrangørerne er frivillige, oplægsholderne er frivillige, lokalerne er lånt gratis ud. Det er fantastisk.

Vi har brug for din støtte til at:

  • Pynte op og lave skilte med vejvisning på dagen
  • Give vores frivillige bespisning på dagen

Til dette har vi brug for 7.000 kr. Pengene går ubeskåret til eventet.

Samler vi flere penge ind går de ubeskåret til næste års arrangement.

Plakat
Hvis du støtter med min. 50 kr. donerer vi en Venus Venue plakat til dig, som du kan afhente til eventet. Der er forskellige motiver at vælge mellem.

Ønsker du at støtte som virksomhed?
Så tilbyder vi dig:

  • Omtale på vores Instagram og Facebook
  • Omtale på selve dagen
  • Logo på sponsortavle på selve dagen
  • Reklame/flyers direkte i præmie-pose. (50 stk.)

 

Andre måder du kan hjælpe på

Hvis du ikke har mulighed for at hjælpe os med økonomisk støtte, betyder det ikke, at du ikke kan hjælpe os. Du kan:

  • Sørg for at sprede budskabet og inviter dine venner til at komme med.
  • Del vores crowdfunding, så den når ud til flest mulige
  • Følg os på vores sociale medier
  • Skriv til os, hvis du ønsker at hjælpe til som frivillig på selve dagen.

 

Tusind tak for din interesse og støtte!

Vi ses til eventet

Lørdag d. 23. oktober 2021. Kl. 10.30-22. Huset i Hasserisgade, Aalborg.

story:
Short Summary

Through this fundraising campaign, I am kindly requesting donations and assistance for this project, which is important in order to justly present the case of a genuine idealist, martyr, and patriot named Zvonko Busic. We are willing to presentthis play anywhere there is an interest and a will to hear the story about this remarkable idealist and the timeless love that characterized Zvonko and Julienne Busic (also convicted and sent to prison for 13 years; she waited faithfully for him for the entire 32 years.)

What We Need & What You Get

Equipment needed for the play: 

- 2 projectors – in order to show archival materials on the big screen, many of which will be available and presented to the Croatian public for the first time

- 3 reflectors, lighting, because not all the places where the play will be shown have these items

-  2 computers, which will contain and store archival materials

- costumes for the actors

- expenses for the booklet, showboard, and promo materials 

- expenses related to the basic fee for the preparation of the play, which will require three  months, sith the premiere planned for the beginning of February, 2018, in Zagreb

- expenses regarding the rental of a van or another vehicle so that the equipment can be transported in future tours around Croatia and abroad

• Total expenses, without the rent of a vehicle, are approximately 80-100 thousand kuna, or 12-15 thousand euro (14 – 18 thousand US dollars), and are mostly  related to absolutely necessary technical props.

About the author

Tihomir Dujmović has been a Croatian journalist and publicist for 30 years.

He has published eight books and a DVD about Cardinal Alojzije Stepinac.

He has written for numerous daily and weekly newspapers in Croatia, and for 12 years, he has hosted political talk shows on various local TV stations. Over the past year, he hosted a talk show on public television.

For three years, Dujmović was the editor-in-chief of the most listened-to radio station in Zagreb, and for seven years the owner of the most listened-to radio station in Rijeka and its surrounding county.

Today he publishes a column on the portal direktno.hr

story:
Who is Ley Line?

We create songs inspired by traditional folklore and languages of the places we visit. Compositions rooted in blues, soul, and folk are infused with rhythms from Brazil, Latin America and West Africa. At home and abroad, we use music to connect us to our community. As artists and educators, our performances create spaces to celebrate language, culture, and the depth of human experience.

We've worked as mentors and educators with organizations and service projects including:

  • Amala Foundation
  • Fuel Our Fire: One Village Music Project
  • International Peace Initiatives
  • Creative Action
  • Boys and Girls Club
  • Origens
  • Mainspring School

And donated our time and performance in partner with GirlForward, Rosedale School, Casa Marianella, and ConnectHer, 

 

The Project:

Together we are traveling over 3,500 miles through Brazil from Porto Alegre to Recife, documenting our collaborations with local artists, organizations and communities through music and film.

Through your support we will be able to complete:

  • A VISUAL ALBUM: A self directed documentation of the process of creating music on the road, inspired by the people and places we visit in Brazil. Meant for both our eyes and our ears, a visual album is a creative intersection of music and film.
  • SERVICE PROJECTS: We believe in the power of grassroots movements to unite people across differences. We will be working as music mentors, leading workshops with youth to facilitate personal growth and cross cultural understanding. Organizations include:
    • ​Colegio Joao Paulo I Unidade Sul
    • Projeto Coração da Terra

      and more to come...

  • TOUR: We will playing more than 20 shows from June to August at cultural centers, festivals, and in the beauty of Brazil's natural world. Through a fusion of many genres, languages, and instruments, our concerts create spaces for authentic listening.

 

Why Brazil?

The music of Brazil is an expression of the diverse tapestry of cultures and histories that shape the country. We use folk music to explore the sonic link across borders and boundaries.  

Austin natives, Kate and Emilie, began their duo in Brazil and continue to revisit the country; working with local musicians and learning traditional folklore. Now it’s time for the completed group to return to where it all began. Lydia and Madeleine's exploration of Brazilian rhythm and the Portuguese language will facilitate performances and workshops that the band will host in Austin upon their return. 

 

Your Contribution:

Your support will bring you along on our journey through video updates, exclusive pre-releases and invitations to special events leading up to the launch of the album.

Our goal of raising $30,000 will fund:

  • Visual Album Production: $10,000 (includes audio engineers and post production)
  • Patronage for local organizations: $4,000
  • Travel: $10,000

To and from Brazil: $4,000

Ground transportation: $6,000

  • Lodging: $1,000
  • Camera Equipment:  $1,500
  • Post tour events and community outreach: $3,500

 

Risks and Challenges:

Brazil is in a time of political turmoil and we understand that strikes and public demonstrations might alter our travel plans. In these moments, we will focus on sharing our authentic experience and documenting the resiliency that comes with creativity and freedom of expression. We will remain fluid and flexible in the face of the challenges that travel can unexpectedly present. There might be a delay in delivering electronic media and we ask for your patience.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Please share our campaign with friends and families through social media and word of mouth!

Connect with us! We are part of a global network of artists and organizations uniting through music and service. We are open to sharing ideas and opportunities to continue this work for years to come. If you or someone you know has a similar vision, we want to hear about it!

 

This is only the beginning...

This is the first step towards Ley Line becoming a self sufficient audio and video production team. Your support in this project provides the solid foundation needed to launch our careers in service,  education and music; capturing encounters and fostering cross cultural relationships around the world. And Brazil is only the beginning...

story:
Short Summary

Living in New Orleans I have met such wonderful and open minded people. I have also met a lot of young men and women you are looking for a place to explore and learn about alternative spirituality but do not feel they can either where they live or in overly public places. There are also an abundant of well-informed spiritual teachers, authors, and readers who are looking to share that information and yet have a hard time finding locations that can accommodate. 

The Witch's Library plans to be an open space where anyone can come, choose from a variety of spiritually informative books, and can sit, read, drink coffee, and chat with other like-minded individuals. We also plan to be a space where teachers can come and hold workshops, movie nights, and other events that are meant to bring together the amazingly mystical community New Orleans holds dear. We plan to run off of love donations raised during events.

What We Need & What You Get

 

What if I don't live in New Orleans? We plan to live stream classes, allowing you to watch, participate, and engage in this amazing community we are creating.

While everything listed here is in the form of monetary, we will happily take donations to supplement!

  • $6000 - 6 months of rent
  • $1200 - 6 months of ulitilies
  • $1000 - Tables and Chairs
  • $500 - Shelving units
  • DONATIONS - Books
  • DONATED - Printer
  • $150 - Printing supplies
  • $200 - Projector
  • $100 - Lamps and Lighting
  • $100 - Cups and refreshment supplies
  • $100 - Microwave
  • $200 - Coffee and tea supply plus single serve brewer
  • $200 - Desk for volunteers
  • $100 - Mini-fridge to store refreshments
  • $300 - Professional handy-help needed to install shelves and other moving needs
  • $300 - Misc supplies
  • DONATED - Website
  • The rest to go funding fees and reward costs

The Impact

We've met so many people here in New Orleans who want to a space where they can ask questions, feel welcome learn from a large array of available books, and take classes

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute please share!

And that's all there is to it.
