story:
Studio Current is an artist run, culture creating, subterranean laboratory in the heart of Seattle's Capitol Hill arts district. Our mission is to enliven creative practice for everybody.

SC is a low cost performance venue, a multidisciplinary rehearsal space, and a champion of experimental art. We hosts classes, workshops, and a 9 month long artist residency program with about 10- 15 artists each season.

  • Artistic Director Katherine Cohen and our Managing Artist Directors - the MAD team  -Angelina Baldoz, Markeith Wiley, Laura Aschoff, and Elby Brosch are working artists that care about creative process, practice, and continuing to develop SC as a community resource. 
  • This fundraising is vital to sustaining SC through the 2017/18 season.
  • We can't do it without your help! We are a grassroots organization running on magic but as it turns out we also need money to keep up the good work. 
  • Our major goals include
    - Sustaining our residency program
    - Remaining an affordable venue in the heart of the Capitol Hill Arts District 
    - Keeping Studio Current an inclusive safe space for queers, POC's and other nonconformists and experimenters.

What We Need & What You Get

And now it's time for the break down:

We hope to raise the $16000 needed to sustain us through the remainder of our 2017/2018 season. This is not all it takes to run this space, but your financial support is an integral part of the process! We can't do it without you! We have a few FunKy perks! Studio Current loves you! These funds go directly toward our rent - it's the majority of our overhead - and other costs like insurance, utilities, supplies like light bulbs, paint brushes, bandaids, cleaners, and other various administrative fees. 

Impact

Your help really does make all the difference. It bridges the gap between the passion, time, and energy we have about maintaining SC and all of the expenses involved in actually doing so. 

  • What is the trajectory of an artist? Experimentation, connection, failures, successes - it's very different for all of us. It's so crucial that artists have time, space, and support to discover and work their process so that they can fully find what it is they do without always having to fit themselves or their work in a box. We are committed to providing this opportunity.
  • Our last Indiegogo fundraiser you helped us raise $10,000 - wow! Thank you! You helped sustain Season II of our Artist residency program and helped us install a fancy new sprung dance floor. Season III is underway with 10 AIRs and 5 Directors + many renters enjoying the renovated studio space, our multipurpose room, the common area and kitchen - all because of the support we received to help us get settled in our new home.
  • Almost 2 years ago SC's founder Vanessa DeWolf passed the torch in the hopes that the vision could grow and thrive in new ways. The challenge led us to a new space, a new way of organizing, and the awareness that it takes a caring community to sustain this healthy ecosystem of ours - and it's happening! With your help we're continuing to amplify the same idea that creative practice and culture can and should be sustained and supported on every level and in every way possible. SC has made this our mission for 14 years, and much of the performance art and dance Seattle enjoys has been affected by it or directly supported and influenced by it.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Truly $5, $10, $22 makes a big difference for us, but hey, if you don't have the dough to toss our way help us spread the word! Share this link, talk about us, help us make some noise!
  • And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
Studio Current is an artist run, culture creating, subterranean laboratory in the heart of Seattle's Capitol Hill arts district. Our mission is to enliven creative practice for everybody.
SC is a low cost performance venue, a multidisciplinary rehearsal space, and a champion of experimental art. We hosts classes, workshops, and a 9 month long artist residency program with about 10- 15 artists each season.

Artistic Director Katherine Cohen and our Managing Artist Directors - the MAD team  -Angelina Baldoz, Markeith Wiley, Laura Aschoff, and Elby Brosch are working artists that care about creative process, practice, and continuing to develop SC as a community resource. 
This fundraising is vital to sustaining SC through the 2017/18 season.
We can't do it without your help! We are a grassroots organization running on magic but as it turns out we also need money to keep up the good work. 
Our major goals include- Sustaining our residency program- Remaining an affordable venue in the heart of the Capitol Hill Arts District - Keeping Studio Current an inclusive safe space for queers, POC's and other nonconformists and experimenters.

What We Need & What You Get

And now it's time for the break down:
We hope to raise the $16000 needed to sustain us through the remainder of our 2017/2018 season. This is not all it takes to run this space, but your financial support is an integral part of the process! We can't do it without you! We have a few FunKy perks! Studio Current loves you! These funds go directly toward our rent - it's the majority of our overhead - and other costs like insurance, utilities, supplies like light bulbs, paint brushes, bandaids, cleaners, and other various administrative fees. 

Impact
Your help really does make all the difference. It bridges the gap between the passion, time, and energy we have about maintaining SC and all of the expenses involved in actually doing so. 

What is the trajectory of an artist? Experimentation, connection, failures, successes - it's very different for all of us. It's so crucial that artists have time, space, and support to discover and work their process so that they can fully find what it is they do without always having to fit themselves or their work in a box. We are committed to providing this opportunity.
Our last Indiegogo fundraiser you helped us raise $10,000 - wow! Thank you! You helped sustain Season II of our Artist residency program and helped us install a fancy new sprung dance floor. Season III is underway with 10 AIRs and 5 Directors + many renters enjoying the renovated studio space, our multipurpose room, the common area and kitchen - all because of the support we received to help us get settled in our new home.
Almost 2 years ago SC's founder Vanessa DeWolf passed the torch in the hopes that the vision could grow and thrive in new ways. The challenge led us to a new space, a new way of organizing, and the awareness that it takes a caring community to sustain this healthy ecosystem of ours - and it's happening! With your help we're continuing to amplify the same idea that creative practice and culture can and should be sustained and supported on every level and in every way possible. SC has made this our mission for 14 years, and much of the performance art and dance Seattle enjoys has been affected by it or directly supported and influenced by it.

Other Ways You Can Help
Truly $5, $10, $22 makes a big difference for us, but hey, if you don't have the dough to toss our way help us spread the word! Share this link, talk about us, help us make some noise!
And that's all there is to it.

story: As we prepare for the holidays and to spend time with our loved ones, let's take a moment to think about those who are not as blessed as we are.
story_txt: As we prepare for the holidays and to spend time with our loved ones, let's take a moment to think about those who are not as blessed as we are.

story:
The IBCC Digital Archive is an extensive repository of the personal stories of those who served, supported and suffered in the bombing campaigns in WW2, including personal memorabilia and one of the biggest collections of eyewitness testimonies.  It is being created to ensure that the story of the Command is preserved in perpetuity and made freely available to inform and educate future generations.

The archive is, essentially, preserving the war the way that people who suffered and served during that time experienced it. It has preserved documents from all over the world, including log books, photographs, letters, diaries and service citations. It also contains oral histories of those involved, from all sides ensuring that their first-hand experiences are not forgotten.

There are over 200,000 documents and 1,800 oral testimonies that have already been protected.

Images of a night anti-aircraft tracer ad a day attack on Philips radio and valve works in Einhoven, courtesy of Peter Banks.

We have already lost many veterans and their immediate families to the passing of time, and with them their war may have already been forgotten. It is imperative that we remember the sufferers and survivors of this world changing conflict and the immense, every day bravery they showed when fighting for our future.

Who knows where we would be without them?

Now it is our turn to fight for their futures. Ladies and gentlemen, we need you!

We are launching this campaign to raise £20,000 to help ensure they will not be forgotten. This will enable us to:

  • Send researchers to record the stories of surviving members of the Bomber Command
  • Set up and staff a new department within the centre to manage the IBCC Digital Archive
  • Purchase equipment that will enable us to digitalise documents, both personal and military, and preserve their integrity
  • Ensure this endangered heritage is preserved
  • Provide a free-to-access portal for research and education
  • Educate generations to come

Our archive is an incredible resource and is completely free for everybody to access online, it not only ensures the heritage is preserved but it helps to bring those involved to life through their personal documents and stories. It is an invaluable tool for anyone with an interest in aviation heritage, military heritage, 20th century history and those doing family research.

To understand the true importance of this fantastic resource visit it by following this link: IBCC Digital Archive

For those who entrust a particularly generous donation to the cause we will be thanking you with extra special gifts. These include:

  • Limited edition prints signed by veterans
  • Limited edition gold IBCC coins which feature metal from a WW2 Lancaster.
  • Life time IBCC membership

All proceed raised from this campaign will go towards remembering those who suffered and served during WWII and we are eternally grateful for the generous support from everyone who has donated. After all, these men and women risked their lives for our freedom, it is the very least we can do to ensure they will be remembered and commemorated in the future.

This campaign is time sensitive which heightens the urgency and need for funds. Don’t let these truly remarkable men and women be forgotten.

On behalf of the team here, I would like to thank you for your generosity and the important role you have played in preserving history.

Group of air and ground crew standing on a Halifax, courtesy of Dennis Raettig
story_txt:
The IBCC Digital Archive is an extensive repository of the personal stories of those who served, supported and suffered in the bombing campaigns in WW2, including personal memorabilia and one of the biggest collections of eyewitness testimonies.  It is being created to ensure that the story of the Command is preserved in perpetuity and made freely available to inform and educate future generations.The archive is, essentially, preserving the war the way that people who suffered and served during that time experienced it. It has preserved documents from all over the world, including log books, photographs, letters, diaries and service citations. It also contains oral histories of those involved, from all sides ensuring that their first-hand experiences are not forgotten.There are over 200,000 documents and 1,800 oral testimonies that have already been protected.Images of a night anti-aircraft tracer ad a day attack on Philips radio and valve works in Einhoven, courtesy of Peter Banks.We have already lost many veterans and their immediate families to the passing of time, and with them their war may have already been forgotten. It is imperative that we remember the sufferers and survivors of this world changing conflict and the immense, every day bravery they showed when fighting for our future.Who knows where we would be without them?Now it is our turn to fight for their futures. Ladies and gentlemen, we need you!We are launching this campaign to raise £20,000 to help ensure they will not be forgotten. This will enable us to:
Send researchers to record the stories of surviving members of the Bomber Command
Set up and staff a new department within the centre to manage the IBCC Digital Archive
Purchase equipment that will enable us to digitalise documents, both personal and military, and preserve their integrity
Ensure this endangered heritage is preserved
Provide a free-to-access portal for research and education
Educate generations to come
Our archive is an incredible resource and is completely free for everybody to access online, it not only ensures the heritage is preserved but it helps to bring those involved to life through their personal documents and stories. It is an invaluable tool for anyone with an interest in aviation heritage, military heritage, 20th century history and those doing family research.To understand the true importance of this fantastic resource visit it by following this link: IBCC Digital ArchiveFor those who entrust a particularly generous donation to the cause we will be thanking you with extra special gifts. These include:
Limited edition prints signed by veterans
Limited edition gold IBCC coins which feature metal from a WW2 Lancaster.
Life time IBCC membership
All proceed raised from this campaign will go towards remembering those who suffered and served during WWII and we are eternally grateful for the generous support from everyone who has donated. After all, these men and women risked their lives for our freedom, it is the very least we can do to ensure they will be remembered and commemorated in the future.This campaign is time sensitive which heightens the urgency and need for funds. Don’t let these truly remarkable men and women be forgotten.On behalf of the team here, I would like to thank you for your generosity and the important role you have played in preserving history.Group of air and ground crew standing on a Halifax, courtesy of Dennis Raettig

story:
The Vision

The vision for the Culture Advocate Network is to build resilient communities founded in acceptance and love of their culture ambassadors. How? First, we build a growing social network of the culture ambassadors (i.e. refugees) currently living in our communities. Once the benefits of cultural diversity are realized, we hope for CAN to be an integral part of the resettlement process globally. Our goal is for the Culture Advocate Network to be utilized by government, non-governmental, and local organizations/agencies around the world in the decades to come as we face this era of human re-distribution.

The Inspiration

This journey started when I first stepped foot in South Terrebonne Parish, Louisiana in 2013 - home to the first climate migrants of the U.S. In the time I spent there for (my thesis), I asked myself: 

How do you get a communities of people to move from a place they have called home for generations? What can be done to preserve the cultures of those that are forcibly displaced? How can we ensure peaceful and sustainable migrations? What will it take for us to see migration as a viable form of adaptation to climate impacts, especially when there is no other option?

These questions led me to create Vanishing Points (TM) along side Jonathan Foret, the Executive Director of a local non-profit called the South Louisiana Wetlands Discovery Center. This website serves as an archive for culturally significant locations in South Louisiana.  Not only does it capture memories and their culture, Vanishing Points (TM) also serves an educational platform for the new communities these residents will move into.

After handing Vanishing Points (TM) over to the SLWDC, I thought - there has to be value in doing this on a global scale. 

Your contribution to the start-up costs The Culture Advocate Network will bring years of learning and research to fruition. This is a pioneering social enterprise that will address a global issue that affects us all. With your support, you will be helping to make our communities stronger, more resilient, and pave the way for a more peaceful transition into this new era human re-distribution.  

 

The Facts

 

The Product

The Culture Advocate Network is designed to be a social network platform that features the stories and cultures of refugees and climate migrants (aka culture ambassadors). Individuals and/or families will be able to set up profiles such as the one below. Community members (aka culture advocates) will also be able to create simplified profiles to welcome, learn about, and support the culture ambassadors in their community. 

 

The Needs

As with any tech start-up, our needs mainly lie in the compensation of a development team. Other members of our start-up team that will receive compensation are listed below as well. If we don't reach our entire goal, the raised funds will first go towards the development team. 

 

The Impact

For our communities today:

Currently less than 1% of all refugees resettle. Resettlement is a miracle, something to be celebrated and supported, yet often we isolate the refugees in our communities. We, the very people that crave international foods and go travel the world, turn a blind eye to the world that resides in our communities. There are rich cultures and relationships just waiting to be unveiled.

Benefits of The Culture Advocate Network for today include:

  • Foster culture ambassador integration and empowerment
  • Increase cultural awareness and acceptance
  • Encourage intergenerational interactions and relationships
  • Provide a safe, positive learning space for the youth 
  • Re-learn 'the basics' - values of community, collaboration, family, healthy social interactions & activities, etc
  • Prime communities for future in-flow of culture ambassadors 

 

For our communities in the future: 

“Right now, we are facing a man-made disaster of a global scale. Our greatest threat in thousands of years: Climate change. If we don’t take action, the collapse of our civilisations and the extinction of much of the natural world is on the horizon.”

— Sir David Attenborough, COP24 (UN Climate Change Conference 2018)

Trying to predict the number of climate migrants in the future is a herculean feat, to say the least. The complexity of climate migration leaves us with wild estimates, ranging from 200 million to 1 billion people. We could run models incessantly and argue tirelessly about the numbers as we once did when we first started talking about climate change.  Or, we can accept this era of human re-distribution and prepare for it.  On the to do list: provide legal rights for the environmentally displaced and accept migration as a viable form of adaptation.

Benefits of the Culture Advocate Network for the future include: 

  • Showcase that resettled peoples can thrive after forced migration
  • Provide evidence to support the legal protection of climate migrants 
  • Support smooth and peaceful transitions of the environmentally displaced 
  • Inspire and encourage pro-active adaptation planning for environmentally threatened communities

 

The Risks & Challenges

Let's face it, this is a United States start-up wanting to address a global issue that our leaders are unwilling to support. Our most influential leaders are absent in the global conversation and efforts preventing, combating, and adapting to climate impacts. There are many that find this topic controversial as well.

These could serve as major hurdles, but I have faith in the power of the people. Thanks to movements such as #RefugeesWelcome, there has been a rise of people with open hearts and minds that I believe will overcome the odds and help make the Culture Advocate Network a global success. This is a 'Love your neighbor' mission and in the end, love conquers all. 

 

The Start-Up Team

At the moment, we are building our CAN's start-up team. I believe it is important to leave space for grace, so I welcome anyone who feels called to CAN's mission to contact me at info@cultureadvocatenetwork.org. We we update this section of our campaign as team members are selected. 

 

Many thanks and blessings to you all!

Thank you so much for your contributions and support to this campaign! It is such a blessing to have you join me on this journey. You are truly helping to make this world a better place! 

If you are not able to contribute at this moment, no worries - I understand. Your thoughts and prayers are just as appreciated! You can help us greatly if you spread the word as well and share this campaign using the handy share tools Indiegogo provides.

story:
2020 ITASA East Coast Conference: Recognize to Reconnect

The Intercollegiate Taiwanese American Students Association (ITASA) is a national 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that seeks to connect, inspire, and empower Taiwanese American students across the country. The ITASA East Coast Conference (ECC) is an annual 3 day conference where attendees from different Taiwanese-American Student Associations get together to learn more about their Taiwanese identities through workshops, connect with others, and enjoy fun social events. Each year, ECC brings together over 200 students from across the east coast to share in the celebration of their culture and to learn to leverage their identities and grow in their professional development.

 

About the Conference

The 2020 theme, Recognize to Reconnect, focuses on the importance of recognizing our Taiwanese identity and the value of reconnecting with our culture to fully embrace our heritage.

Held this year at the University of Maryland, College Park, from February 6-9, 2020, the conference will feature workshops with Taiwanese-American changemakers from across the country with themes about the importance of self, culture, and community. We will also be hosting a nationally-recognized keynote speaker with the hope that these messages will inspire the ECC attendees to realize these ideas and inspirations in their own lives, causing an impact beyond the weekend of the conference. 

 

Why Should I Support This Campaign?

The 2020 ECC team at the University of Maryland is comprised of college students, all working hard on a pro bono basis. The conference is estimated to cost about $20,000, with major parts of the budget including the cost of workshop speakers, venue reservations, and other operational costs. To reach that goal, we are also working to secure funding from sources such as the University of Maryland SGA and our own fundraising initiatives. Your generous financial support would be greatly appreciated to help us reach our minimum goal of $1000, which we hope to exceed. You will also contribute to the cause of empowering a rising generation of Taiwanese-American youths.

We sincerely ask for your support to help us bring the Taiwanese-American community together to share our narratives and amplify our voices during this very special event. As a national 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, your donations to us will be tax-deductible.

 

Workshop Tracks

Recognize: ­­­The workshops for this track will focus on the identities that attendees may have pushed aside or not yet discovered. Speakers will share about how they recognized their own identities and how doing so helped to shape who they are today. 

Reconnect: During the workshops for this track, speakers will teach students the importance of self, culture, and community through interactive activities. 

Represent: The workshops for this session will focus on embracing one’s Taiwanese identity and increasing Asian-American representation in media and entertainment, technology, business, leadership, or management. 

 

List of Schools In Attendance

Baruch College

Boston College

Brown University

Columbia University

Cornell University 

Harvard University

Johns Hopkins University

Massachusetts Institute of Technology

New York University

Parsons School of Design

Princeton University

Stony Brook University 

Rutgers University

University of Maryland

University of Pennsylvania

Yale University

 

For any questions regarding the conference and how you can help, contact umcp2020@itasa.org for more info. See everything at http://umcp2020.itasa.org/

story:
What is Raindance?

Raindance Film Festival is the UK's largest and oldest independent film festival. We celebrated our 25th-anniversary last year – a very significant landmark for an independent film festival, as you will see.

The festival has run independently for 25 years thanks to our members, private donors, cultural partners and sponsors. Raindance relies on the community of filmmakers and independent film lovers to achieve its mission in 2018.

 

Your pledge helps achieve these objectives:

  • Keep discounted tickets for under 25s, students, senior citizens, claimants, first responders and carers.
  • Support filmmakers from disadvantaged backgrounds to attend the festival
    (the 25x25 project in collaboration with the Independent Film Trust - a registered charity)
  • Develop a cutting-edge festival app to cut down on paper waste.
  • Keep our commemorative catalogue FREE and printed on (more expensive) eco-friendly paper.
  • Provide access for audiences with hearing and visual disabilities to festival screenings and seminars
  • Keep independent cinema alive in Leicester Square.

- - - - - - - - - - - - -

Ways you can help Raindance:

Donate and tell your friends! It's that simple.

Each and every donation, no matter how large or small, is most gratefully received.
Help us achieve our objectives.

Donate - have a look at our perks
or
Help us spread the word about this vital campaign!
- - - - - - - - - - - - -

Filmmakers on 'Why Raindance is important'

- - - - - - - - - - - - -

Share the message!

Sample tweets for you to use:

Champion #IndieFilm in the UK by donating to the @Raindance Film Festival 2018 crowdfunding campaign https://igg.me/at/raindance2018

Help @Raindance attract wider audiences, and to meet our environmental and sustainability goals in 2018 https://igg.me/at/raindance2018 #diversity #Londonisopen

Help to keep independent film in Leicester Square by donating to the @Raindance Film Festival 2018 #crowdfunding campaign https://igg.me/at/raindance2018

Support #IndieFilm and independent voices by donating to the @Raindance Film Festival 2018 crowdfunding campaign https://igg.me/at/raindance2018

Help @Raindance Film Festival continue enabling independent voices https://igg.me/at/raindance2018

Help to make #IndieFilm accessible to everyone by donating to the @Raindance Film Festival 2018 crowdfunding campaign https://igg.me/at/raindance2018

- - - - - - - - - - - - -

Some of the Perks!


- - - - - - - - - - - - -

A 'Big Thanks' from the Raindance team

We welcome your questions, ideas, suggestions or feedback
Please email festival producer David Martinez, david@raindance.co.uk
Or call us +44 (0)207 930 3412
We love hearing from you!
- - - - - - - - - - - - -

About Raindance

Since 1993, Raindance has promoted and exhibited independent film through an annual 12-day festival in the heart of London’s buzzing West End district.

Raindance gives independent films a bold innovative platform to reach wider audiences of film-lovers and film industry professionals.  Acquisition executives, talent agents, financiers, talent scouts and film sales agents attend to see hidden gems unavailable elsewhere.
- - - - - - - - - - - - -

What they are saying:

“Raindance is responsible for the resurgence of filmmaking in the UK and deserves your support” Ken Loach

“The Raindance Film Festival and BIFA make a unique and very special contribution to independent film in the UK. They should be taken very seriously”
Mike Leigh

“In its efforts to discover and promote new talent, Raindance is an asset to the British film industry today”
Nick Powell

“Britain’s largest and most exciting independent film festival, as likely to generate hit films as any of its mainstream rivals”
The Guardian

“One of the top-50 unmissable film festivals"
Variety

“The indie-est film festival this side of the Atlantic”
The Guardian

- - - - - - - - - - - - -


- - - - - - - - - - - - -

Our objectives and challenges for 2018

Running a film festival is always a challenge!  And - as devastating as it feels to admit - without your support, there is a real risk that we will not be able to keep our 2017 ticket costs and provide access to a wider audience through discounted rates, support for disabled audiences and help underrepresented talent break into the film industry.

Raindance will never cease to support independent film and filmmakers - but all your donations and support will ensure to increase our access to the benefit of British independent film.

Rewards offered by Raindance through this important campaign will be completed in full as personal thanks our supporters who share the same independent and free spirit.

They should be taken very seriously”Mike Leigh“In its efforts to discover and promote new talent, Raindance is an asset to the British film industry today”Nick Powell“Britain’s largest and most exciting independent film festival, as likely to generate hit films as any of its mainstream rivals”The Guardian“One of the top-50 unmissable film festivals"Variety“The indie-est film festival this side of the Atlantic”The Guardian- - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - -Our objectives and challenges for 2018Running a film festival is always a challenge!  And - as devastating as it feels to admit - without your support, there is a real risk that we will not be able to keep our 2017 ticket costs and provide access to a wider audience through discounted rates, support for disabled audiences and help underrepresented talent break into the film industry.Raindance will never cease to support independent film and filmmakers - but all your donations and support will ensure to increase our access to the benefit of British independent film.Rewards offered by Raindance through this important campaign will be completed in full as personal thanks our supporters who share the same independent and free spirit.

story:
Southside Skatepark is seeking support in funding the down payment on a commercial loan which we have been approved for.  This loan would allow us to move Southside Skatepark from our current rental agreement to a facility we own.  The reduction in operation cost will allow for a better skateboarding facility for the region.  We are hoping to achieve our down payment goal by early 2018, enter into negotiation on a building in January and open the doors no later then March 2018.  

Southside Skatepark established in 1994 has been home to 20 years of the Texas Skate Jam benefiting the Make a Wish Foundation and in that time has helped raise almost $1,000,000 in total donations. More recently we partnered with the skateboarding industry in launching #icleanedoutmyclosetforhouston to provide relief for Hurricane Harvey survivors in need. Our relief efforts continue in the wake of this tragedy to this day. 

Southside Skatepark provides a place to congregate and skateboard in peace. We work hard to provide the best indoor skatepark experience in the City of Houston, with it's difficult weather patterns. Southside has hosted many generations of regional up and coming skateboarders in their pursuit of a career in skateboarding. Now is the time to relocate Southside Skatepark and position it to continue tradition for another 23 years of skateboarding. We are committed to providing you an even better indoor skatepark experience at our new facility. We hope you will join us by making a donation, sharing this Kickstarter and doing anything you can to spread the word and keep Southside Skatepark open and operating in Houston for years to come. - Big O, Southside Skatepark

Risks and challenges

Skateparking itself can be very challenging and in 2017 privately run skateparks are few and far between. Southside Skatepark has been operating in South Houston since 1994 and we have been operating Southside since 2007. Those eleven years of experience have been very valuable and allowed us to develop the skills necessary to accomplish this task. We are moving Southside Skatepark to a facility we own in an effort to insure the support of skateboarding in this region for many more years to come.

story:
Our Story

Our story is a dialogue of cultural flavours between Druze, Christian and Muslim cooks, ingredients and local producers from Israel’s Galilee. Through co-operation and a common love of cooking, we will bring you the rich tastes of traditional Galilean food in a recipe book, so that you can experience this unique cuisine whilst we indulge you in the culinary tales of our cooks and the terroir.

For over 30 years, Ruth Nieman & Paul Nirens have in very different ways been connected with food of the Galilee. By joining forces with their knowledge and enthusiasm for the abundant produce that makes this area so very unique, we are ready to put pen to paper and invite you into the homes of the locals and show off the regional food and culinary culture.

We are two Jewish ‘foodies’ from opposite parts of the globe, whose passion, experiences and adventures with food and cooking workshops of Galileat, found a way of bringing us together and into The Galilean Kitchen…. a cookbook with a difference.

Our Cookbook:

The Galilean Kitchen is more than just a recipe book. It is unique in that it displays the very essence of the ethnic and seasonal journey that we will take you on, whilst showing the many ways to prepare authentic dishes like sinye, maklouba and hubeza, that have passed through the generations.

The stories of the women, their heritage, the cultural influences in their cooking together with their own take on the traditional food, give all our recipes credibility and defines the Galilean kitchens of today.

Using local, seasonal and wild ingredients of the land we will bring you variations on each recipe, as well as featuring alternatives for you to try in your own kitchen.

What We Need & What You Get

The Galilean Kitchen is a personal, social, ethical and cultural project that we both feel very passionate about and is very close to both of our hearts. Galilean food and cooking is still relatively unknown outside the region and we feel that now is the time for the flavours and recipes to gain recognition in kitchens around the globe, inviting culinary interest, respect and collaboration.

Our joint experiences of food, cooking, Israel and the Galilee gives us the confidence to produce a cookbook of the highest quality. We have enlisted a well-respected photographer and a graphic designer with other published cookbooks to her name, but we need your backing to ensure its success.

We are looking to raise $25,000 to produce, publish and distribute the first edition of The Galilean Kitchen.

Most of our expenses will be covered through book pre-orders on our Indiegogo campaign, so for $30 place your order for a 'first edition' of The Galilean Kitchen and experience the cultural flavours of this bountiful region.   

For $50, you will receive an autographed first edition, signed by the authors Ruth Nieman and Paul Nirens as well as our photographer Neil Mercer.

There are also many other ways to help us achieve our goal and ensure the success of the project with attractive rewards that capture the flavour of the book. These include locally sourced spices and olive oil beauty products, which give authenticity to the recipes, as well as the ultimate perk of a cooking workshop, with hands-on cooking of local food in the kitchen of one of our experienced, hospitable cooks.

The Impact

Your generosity in pre-ordering The Galilean Kitchen together with pledging your support for our perks will help us fulfil our ambition of publishing this beautiful cookbook. At the same time, you will be helping us promote co-operation between all the people of the Galilee.

Thank you….

Ruth, Paul, Neil & Lisa

story:
TERANIM Centre for Popular Arts is an independent cultural institution founded in 2014. It is concerned with reviving the Mauritanian folklore which is subjected to extinction, it focuses on the culture and arts of the decedents of the former slaves in order to reexamine it and its practitioners through the approach of art in the service of rights, for building a diverse Mauritanian society able to live together culturally and interested in arts.

We work hard through the festival of Layaly Elmedih to continue this humanitarian message. So that this music singers could regain their exploited humanity.

We need you to stand by us in achieving their simple dreams which are preserving their culture and their heritage from extinction due their poverty.

Your contribution in funding the festival will make the difference and help in spreading and preserving this heritage.

Since 2014 TERANIM Centre for popular arts has launched an annual festival to preserve this heritage. However this youth initiative is threatened by the lack of funding and the absence of official sponsors for five years

We need 10.000 $ representing 60 % of the budget for the sixth edition of the festival

This amount will be paid in the following items

Technical and logistic

3,000

Wages for technical teams

2,500

Training workshop

2,800

Documentation

1,700

This is the sixth edition for this festival and we were doing this based on ourselves and every time we had to decrease the period or the number of participates because we don’t have the enough amount to do that. And that is the same thing that we are going to do if we did not get the enough amount in order to let our activities continuing in every year.

From the importance of culture diversity expressions with traditional forms and values that allow people to express their ideas, opinions and traditions and to share them with others around the world.

This campaign concerns all people around the world and all people are commanded to share it to reach all people around the world. And that was the same way that helped this campaign to have donating nationally, and sharing the post on Facebook made this campaign succeeding in Mauritania.

As it represent an opportunity for many practitioners of this musical style to show their talents to a large audience. It's main mission is to preserve this popular heritage from extinction in a context where culture is not particularly important, including those who seek to preserve marginal culture or marginalised group for known historical reasons.

After the ending of the festival all people can see what happened during it, by visiting the site of TERANIM and pages on social media. And that will allow them to see their participating have impact in the success of this festival. TERANIM center will give some words includes some kind of the festival.

story:
The original theater was designed by architect Oreste C.S. Ziroli and constructed at the turn of the 20th century, first operating in 1920 as a vaudeville house. Still intact today, albeit in need of significant repairs and upgrades, are its proscenium arch, art deco marquee, and interior structures.  

Looking to the future of the theater and furthering reinforcing its significance within the town, the community’s support through personal contributions will “Light the Marquee” and solidify a permanent place in the theater’s history.

While gifts are not tax deductible, 100% of the funds raised will go towards the purchase of the theater chairs, staging, lighting, and amenities.

story:
Summary

Nestled in San Juan La Laguna, Guatemala on the Northwestern shore of Lake Atitlán, Something magical is being planted.

Nuestra Casa is a sustainable micro hotel that will focus on housing groups when they come to do volunteer work for local nonprofits and other impactful projects. Its goal is to support education in the area of San Juan La Laguna.

Although Nuestra Casa may be a fairly new concept, it has grown out of 18 years of working closely in Guatemala with local school children and the community.

Nuestra Casa will not only provide lodging for visitors, but will also provide a space for people of the community to host meetings and special events. All proceeds from the project will be used to support education in the community.

The site is situated on a long stretch of land measuring 13,200 square meters. Although the site is long and narrow, it is a marvelous setting for an interesting and challenging architectural design, being located on a site with a beautiful landscape and amazing views.

Nuestra Casa is envisioned to be a space that provides guests with comfort, security and exposure to the native Mayan culture that surrounds the site. Utilizing public and private space, with controlled access, the space will provide lodging for groups and separate lodging for leaders when requested.

It will also feature common areas to reconnect, socialize, and hold group activities, or to prepare and share meals. The design attempts to infuse the culture onto the site in a unique manner that interacts with the natural surroundings. At the same time, Nuestra Casa will benefit the students from the surrounding community economically. All funds that are generated through Nuestra Casa will be used for education – financial provision for schools, generating scholarships, and strategic support for workshops and job training.

 

WERKER is helping raise funds and create the design for Nuestra Casa to become a reality. This will be achieved through fundraising, raising awareness, and creating the best design that encompasses all the needs and expectations of the project.

 

Goals of Nuestra Casa

· Establish sustained support for the New Dawning Christian School

· Create a clean and safe housing for volunteer service groups.

· Provide visitors with access to Lake Atitlan, the village of San Juan La Laguna, and surrounding villages.

· Bolster support for local businesses

· Promote a cross-pollination of cultures through cultural exchanges

· Create jobs for local individuals

· Initiate support for local service projects

· Provide additional educational resources for the broader community

· Create new opportunities for service and education

 

What we NEED

In order to make the new project happen, we are trying to raise $50,000 to fund the first phase of the project. – These funds will help with the construction and materials to build phase 1 of the new group hotel.

 

Team

Tom Palmer - Visionary

Brent Bromstrup - Visionary

Tom King - Architectural Designer

Justin Martinez - Creative Director

Maria Fernanda Contreras - Photographer

Angelica Caldera - Copy Direction 

www.wearewerker.com

story:
WHY

People might have started reading and talking about homosexuality, but haven't started accepting it yet.

The root cause of this entire issue is Heteronormativity. It’s that phenomenon where people are so used to seeing heterosexual couples everywhere, that it’s considered a norm.

Due to this social perception, an LGBT individual goes through many issues as seen in the image below.

This process requires DEEP SOCIAL CHANGE. And we intend to do that. 

 

WHAT

The concept is called 'TWINNING LGBT'. It strives to achieve LGBT acceptance by breaking the visual stereotype of Heteronormativity.

They say - 'Seeing is Believing'. So, women of different cultures, ethnicities and race are shown in companionship, twinning in simple, everyday activities. 

Phase 1 focuses on women.

 

 

The point of presenting them individually is to propose togetherness- together. Stand up for the right cause, propose the same belief, stand in solidarity TOGETHER.

 

HOW 

All #TwinningLGBT products are sold in pairs!!

Each product category features a couple, or a couple along with a message each woman conveys.

The messages are given out as poems, love notes or anecdotes. They speak about love, passion, gender identities, sexual preferences, family honour, social acceptance, self - love, hope, inclusion, confidence, individualism, positivity, humanity, etc.

There are also some quirky, cool and meaningful QUOTES which reinforce our respect for the LGBT community.

Coasters, Magnets, T-shirts and Prints are some of the products we have created so far.

Few of them can be seen below:

 

 

 

 

 

 

We're looking to raise £12,000. 50% of the profits will go to a charity called 'House of Rainbow', that works to create a safer and inclusive environment for the LGBT community. The rest will help us set up our first production line for all variants, to promote awareness and create LGBT acceptance.

We hope to have you with us to show compassion and look beyond the barriers that man has set up. Help us change the way people see the world and create a life of love and acceptance for everyone.

 

Below are the links for all rewards with codes: (You will be getting 2 of whatever you choose!)

Please choose your pick and send us the code when you order your perk(s)

1) Magnets: https://imgur.com/a/VlOiH3U

2) Coasters: https://imgur.com/a/1eLL0Ju

3) T-Shirts: https://imgur.com/a/nCrf0Mg

4) Art Prints: https://imgur.com/a/K4Y2o3A

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP:

Share this campaign on social media and with your friends and family! Be sure to tag us @Ravisilove and use the hashtag #TwinningLGBT

Follow us on social media: Instagram, Twitter, and Facebook

story:
Short Summary

Bàta nan Salm 2017 Residency will be a community-based Gaelic Arts residency in the heart of Lochs on the Isle of Lewis exploring, re-enacting, recollecting and retelling the stories of the psalmboats of Loch Erisort. For two weeks in August, Gaelic Psalmsingers, sailors, artists, activists and dreamers will settle in to Old Soval Lodge in Kinloch for workshops, talks, meetings and taigh-chèilidhs. Our trips to landing spots, villages and sites around Loch Erisort will be recorded and filmed – with your help! Traditional sailing skippers and boats from Falmadair sailing club will lead us to re-envisage the often treacherous journeys to worship across wide and deep Loch Erisort.

Bàta nan Salm is a unique Gaelic community. A strong belief in the power of story and voice in the Gaelic imagination underpins the entire project. Respect for the faith traditions of all island people is also central to our aims. We invite you to contribute to achieving a lasting legacy for local people, their friends, families and the worldwide Gaelic community – through drama, sound and film. From these riches we will also plan to create a public archive. Your contribution - no matter how small - will support a truly local, grassroots project through which Gaelic speakers, Psalmsingers, sailors and artist-activists are reclaiming their cultural and spiritual inheritance, for the benefit of all.

story:
At the end of April, In the Soil Arts Festival will celebrate 10 years of bringing our little festival that could to downtown St. Catharines. Showcasing original music, theatre, comedy, literary and visual art, film, wild streetscape installations, interactive workshops and more, In the Soil is like a choose-your-own ART adventure!

We created In the Soil Arts Festival to share the richness of our local arts community. This was before the City of St. Catharines and Brock University decided to invest in the downtown and before the sea change we are currently experiencing here in the core. We are so proud that our festival has been ahead of the curve, demonstrating to our community leaders and members that high-quality arts experiences are at the centre of a vibrant and liveable place.

From Day One, we wanted our festival to serve the artists first. We’ve proudly paid professional standard artist fees to all participating artists and work to provide stellar production and marketing in support of them.

(Pizza Sharks, The Merchant Ale House, ITS 2017. Photo: Lauren Garbutt Photography)

Who we are:

In the Soil Arts Festival is produced by St. Catharines-based not-for-profit Suitcase in Point with the help of founding partners, WOW Recordings, Niagara Artists Centre and Greenbelt Arts. Now entering its 10th year, In the Soil is (and always has been) brought to fruition by the COMMUNITY AT LARGE. Over 150 volunteers, a slew of local businesses, artists and organizations have come together each spring to celebrate the arts in St. Catharines. Together, we share an artistically boundary-pushing event that is by and for our local community.

What funds In the Soil Arts Festival?

With little staff to wheel and deal for support from the private sector, we primarily depend on government grants, followed by sponsorships and tickets sales each year to break even. We’re in a pinch this time around, so as we gear up for Year 10 we are calling on the help of our peers, our neighbours and our friends to contribute financially to help ensure that In the Soil Arts Festival can continue to provide artists and audiences a weekend to remember.

Here's how it breaks down:

What we’re asking:

$10,000 may seem like a hefty amount to ask for, but it is a reality we face this year as we contend with funding shortfalls. By contributing to this campaign, you will be helping us break even in producing our 10th festival. It’s rare that we call on our peers and the community at large to assist financially, but we have little choice this year.

Our expenses are not decadent or luxurious. We pay for production teams and technical staff who care about creating a great experience for the artists as well as the audience. We pay for street closures and tents and heaters and signage. Most of all, we pay for artists of all disciplines to bring incredible contemporary art to every nook and cranny of downtown St. Catharines. 

     

(Massive Band Parade, Festival Hub, ITS 2017. Photo: Lauren Garbutt Photography)

Over the past 10 years we have worked with more than 5,000 artists and attracted more than 25,000 festival-goers to see and experience their work. Each year, we stretch our creativity and our ambitions to their limits to share with our beloved and growing community.

In the Soil Arts Festival has continued to grow in scale and popularity thanks to our community’s support and we need your help to ensure it can continue for years to come.

Please be a part of helping us sustain and grow!   

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry if you can't make a financial contribution. We understand.

There are other ways you can help:

  • You can help us get the word out! Make some noise about our campaign and our tour. Share on Facebook, tweet, and send out shout outs on our behalf.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the good word!
  • Volunteer! Sign up here!

We can't go without saying a HUGE thank you to our supporters:

                  

Video footage from Enns Visuals. Video edit and interviews by FIXT Point.
story_txt:

story:
The Dome at Highfield will be a temporary, outdoor exhibit from June 15, 2018 – October 15, 2018 on the grounds of Highfield Hall & Gardens. The pop-up Dome is produced by The Dome at Woods Hole, a non-profit organization dedicated to the preservation and rehabilitation of The Dome at the Nautilus, built in 1953 by Buckminster Fuller. 

This pop-up Dome is part of Highfield’s summer exhibit entitled “Out of the Box” which will feature the Dome and other environmental sculptures throughout their grounds and gardens.

The Dome at Highfield is a collaborative project between The Dome at Woods Hole and Highfield. In keeping with The Dome at Wood Hole’s mission to create a space and forum for interdisciplinary collaboration, innovative thinking and creative making, The Dome at Highfield will introduce the local and regional community to the sorts of programs The Dome at Woods Hole will offer at its future permanent home.

Through exploratory educational programs, social events and communal gatherings, The Dome at Highfield will create opportunities for visitors to experience how the interaction of art, environment, design and technology will come together at The Dome at Woods Hole.

As we work to preserve and rehabilitate the Dome at Woods Hole, we hope the pop-up Dome will provide a space for questions, conversations, and learning alike. 

What We Need:

In order to build the Dome – we need the materials – specifically 100 2” x 4” x 10feet long boards of pressure-treated Southern Yellow Pine.

We are ‘selling’ each board for $20 which covers the cost of the board, additional materials for construction, and labor.

Designed by Buckminster Fuller's great nephew, architect Deacon Marvel, the pop-up Dome will be a reusable structure, that we intend to bring to additional locations in the future - so your one time contribution will benefit the community for years to come!

In recognition of your contribution, you to will be able to come and sign your board, becoming a permanent part of this dynamic construction! If you are unable to visit the pop-up Dome and sign your own board, your name will be added by one of the local artists from the community to ensure your contribution remains a part of the Dome forever.

If we do not reach our goal, all donations will go towards defraying the cost of materials. 

Programming at the Dome at Highfield:

Visitors to Highfield will have full access to visit The Dome. In addition to educational programming in and around The Dome at Highfield, there will be several special events:

  • A Family Night Concert on Wednesday, July 25th featuring local band Crooked Coast and several local food trucks
  • A Dome fundraising party, open to the community, on Saturday evening, July 7th
  • Bi-weekly tours of the pop-up Dome with a local educator who will provide insight into Fuller's legacy
  • "Build-a-dome" crafting events for families where participants get to build and take home their own dome
  • Parallel events at the Falmouth Public Library -  Main Library - in conjunction with our exhibition on Buckminster Fuller and Geodesic Domes in the Reading Room and Lobby.

More about the Dome at Woods Hole:

The Dome at Woods Hole is a non-profit organization dedicated to the promotion of innovative exploration in the arts and sciences.  Located in Buckminster Fuller’s oldest extant geodesic dome, The Dome will be a multi-disciplinary arts, performance and exhibition center bringing world-class contemporary arts to Woods Hole. The mission of The Dome is to build community around the intersection of art, science, technology and the environment.

Buckminster Fuller designed and built the geodesic dome in Woods Hole, Mass., in 1953. Originally constructed as a restaurant, the Dome has been abandoned since 2002 but has proven its architectural genius by standing the test of time since its creation. This iconic structure, which is eligible for listing on the National Register, is a testament to Fuller’s design, simple use of materials and philosophy to do more with less.

The initiative to rehabilitate and revitalize the Dome is underway by a team of dedicated community members and supporting organizations. Exemplifying Fuller’s passion for comprehensive anticipatory design, The Dome at Woods Hole will have exhibition/performance space, a permanent exhibit about Fuller, studios for artist residencies, hospitality amenities and supporting facilities.

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you are unable to contribute, bring a hammer!

The pop-up Dome is being constructed by community members from June 2-3. If you want to help, we could always use an extra pair of hands! Get in touch with us at info@artdome.org to get involved!  

And please share our campaign with your network using Indiegogo's share tools, or by sharing this link on your social media!

Further reading on the Dome:

Our efforts:

Cape Cod Times

Cape and Islands

Falmouth Enterprise

History of the Dome:

Podcast from 99% Invisible

The Woods Hole Historical Museum's written history of the Dome from James W. Mavor Jr.

story:
Take a Deep Breath Campaign

  • Who: Edward Hill, II - founder of The Infinite Steps to Health Project (www.theishproject.com).
  • Our TADB campaign is used to enhance the cultural meaning of health.
  • This film will be a game changer in what it means to think, discuss, and act on the topic of health, specifically within the African-American community.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal is $15,000.00 and this will go towards renting equipment, travel cost, and more importantly, 10% of these funds will go towards buying fresh produce and delivering it to families within Detroit's inner city.
  • As a nonprofit organization, our funds will go directly towards support of community.

The Impact

There aren't many films that focus on health within the black community. We often see the struggle, but very rarely do we see the beauty around such a topic. We want to change that with this film.

story:
WHO

Welsh researcher, Hannah Ruth Dyson, has been an expert on the history of women’s cultural & spiritual traditions, for the past six years. Her work has been engaged in gathering research, conducting field trips, and offering sacred travel experiences for women.

Holding a BSc, at the London School of Economics, and previous experience in international documentary research, and film production. Hannah’s work, acts as a bridge, to understanding our collective human story, by bringing greater awareness to the female & indigenous perspective.

Soul Seed Gathering was born 3 years ago, halfway into a year-long group project, mapping the historical narrative of women, across the world.

What became quickly apparent, was the lack of research, for the perspective, traditions & wisdom of women, in indigenous cultures across the world, that are still alive and present today.

Soul Seed Gathering seeks to contribute to this body of work.

We work with local women, & NGOs, where appropriate, in each country, who have built long-term relationships, with the indigenous women who live there. This allows us to develop deeper connections, as we work with a new culture and country, each chapter.

Our aim is to document, preserve, and fill any gaps of our understanding, of female traditions and wisdoms, by travelling to the source of these lineages.

We invite women, from around the world, to gather with us, & celebrate our collective cultural heritage.

Together, we weave a cultural tapestry & fabric of knowledge, empowering the perspective of the feminine.

WHY

Thus far, we have been entirely self-funded & remained independent. We are at a moment of transition in our project, where we need to justice by what we have started. This needs your support.

For too long, the female-side of the story has been ignored and not deemed important. It is time to elevate Herstory.

We are mapping women's wisdom traditions across the world, to offer the collective consciousness, a greater understanding of who we are.

In an age where women’s empowerment is a trending topic, do we truly know what is included in the female sphere of power, spirituality and influence across the world?

 

JOIN OUR COMMUNITY OF WEAVERS

if you are...

- spiritual seeking, looking to get to the source of who you are,

- a cultural explorer, trying to understand more of the world,

- looking for guidance, for how best to protect the earth we call home,

- a woman, who wishes to gain a greater sense of depth, in empowerment and community,

- or a man who would love to support, & hold space, for the rise of the feminine.

 

JOIN US

By supporting this Indiegogo campaign, you will help to protect the heritage of women in indigenous groups, allowing us to share a greater understanding of who we are as women, and fund our next two documentary, and sensitive intercultural-exchange trips.

Our next trip is taking place in Brazil, in early 2019, where we are learning from the Guarani elders, known colloquially as the 'ancients'.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Reaching $30,000 will help support our team for one year of operations, including:

two research & documentary trips. The first to learn with Guarani elders in Brazil.

- Join us on our next gathering experience in Brazil, March 2019 as our top gift donation.

the building of the online Soul Seed Media & Research House - a space to share our field trip work, & the wisdom being asked to be protected, by the women we work with.

- Join for first access, with a year subscription, to also gain access to our worldwide community of women.

provision of education materials, to share more of the female cultural story.

- If you are affiliated with a school, business &/or media - this is a great option to support.

 

When we exceed our current funding goals.

$30,000 - $60,000 will allow us to build a strong team to do this work justice & share more educational materials, through media channels

$60,000 - $120,000 will support full-time staff & post-production for the documentary series + film

+ $120,000 will allow us to begin to the process of supporting land reparations, to aid the women we work with directly, and the land that they caretake. Land ownership, helps protect precious natural resources, sustain communities, and protects their heritage, language and traditions that are inter-connected with the land they are indigenous to.

 

The Impact

This work is highly important at this time, as we are witnessing rapid culture loss & land destruction, all over the world.

Ignoring the female & indigenous perspective - in education, academia, & media spaces - negatively impacts us all. At this time, more than ever, we are needing to readdress the balance between: masculine & feminine. We are needing more than the white, male, euro-centric biases, that govern how we operate in the world. 

A reoccurring story, is appearing in our work, where women remember a time, when they were also the leaders, spiritually and in community. Women came together in council, and were highly respected. As colonialism arrived in waves, several generations later, the threads of memory for the way things were, are wearing thin. In some cases, women have been repressed, and in others, sensed a need to protect, and keep their wisdom traditions private.

The women we work with, speak that this is an important moment in time, to speak out and share their message, as they witness the rapid destruction of the Earth & their traditional ways. We seek to support these women, in anyway we can.

After our recent trip to Colombia, we realised the importance of following-through, and doing justice to all that we have set in motion, as we quietly disrupt and change the very fabric of the society we work with, by focusing our attention to only the women. The time is now.

 

Risks & Challenges

The very nature of this work is highly sensitive & delicate, and we will continue to tread carefully.

Too much damage has already been made, by turning a blind eye that allows corporate greed to rear it's ugly head, looking to indigenous as less than, or only as part of our past, allowing for cultural prostitution in the form of tourism, the spread of alcohol, drugs & processed westernised foods, and by good intentions gone wrong, by overemphasising our euro-centric biases & asserting our solutions for the future.

Indigenous peoples are said to make up 8% of our world population, yet protect up to 80% of our Earth's precious biosphere. It is important to learn from them & work with them, for our survival.

Patriarchy & the affects of colonialism, have influenced all of our biases, perspectives & ways of living in the world. By asking, to only work with the women, we are in many ways disrupting and threatening the status quo, and we will continue to take precautionary measures.

We know how to work in intelligent ways, and will continually seek guidance, to learn how to do best, by what we have set in motion.

In some cases, women have requested for their image, voice & message to remain protected, yet still be shared where needed. This ask, has inspired the creation of our Soul Seed House, an online members space. Here, we will be sharing the voice of these women first.

The Soul Seed House & our gatherings, will be a source of ongoing revenue, to continue supporting this work, and to allow community to take part in the journey of our research & documentary work, as well as showcasing contributing members creative abilities, as we empower all women who join us. 

Support

Donate & receive one of the many incredible gifts we have available. If you wish to only donate, and do not with to receive the gift please just let us know at soulseedgathering@gmail.com and we are grateful for your support!

If needing any more information for any of the gifts listed please send questions to the above email listed & we will answer all as they come.

Thank you!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help get our message out! This is the time to share with all your friends, family & community. Use your social influence for good - however big or small. Help us share this important movement.

If you are female-identifying join our #thereismoretoourstory movement.

1. Record yourself speaking the line 'There Is More To Our Story' to camera

2. Share on your social media platform (tagging us, sharing the # & linking the campaign) 

3. + send the video into us at soulseedgathering@gmail.com for us to share within our campaign video. Please add your social media handle in the email, for us to tag you back.

If you are male-identifying you can still join by sharing and recording the line 'There Is More To Her Story' to camera, and still using the same #thereismoretoourstory and sending in to us!

Thanks again!

There Is More To Our Story & we have only just begun...

It is important to learn from them & work with them, for our survival.Patriarchy & the affects of colonialism, have influenced all of our biases, perspectives & ways of living in the world. By asking, to only work with the women, we are in many ways disrupting and threatening the status quo, and we will continue to take precautionary measures.We know how to work in intelligent ways, and will continually seek guidance, to learn how to do best, by what we have set in motion.In some cases, women have requested for their image, voice & message to remain protected, yet still be shared where needed. This ask, has inspired the creation of our Soul Seed House, an online members space. Here, we will be sharing the voice of these women first.The Soul Seed House & our gatherings, will be a source of ongoing revenue, to continue supporting this work, and to allow community to take part in the journey of our research & documentary work, as well as showcasing contributing members creative abilities, as we empower all women who join us. SupportDonate & receive one of the many incredible gifts we have available. If you wish to only donate, and do not with to receive the gift please just let us know at soulseedgathering@gmail.com and we are grateful for your support!If needing any more information for any of the gifts listed please send questions to the above email listed & we will answer all as they come.Thank you! Other Ways You Can HelpHelp get our message out! This is the time to share with all your friends, family & community. Use your social influence for good - however big or small. Help us share this important movement.If you are female-identifying join our #thereismoretoourstory movement.1. Record yourself speaking the line 'There Is More To Our Story' to camera2. Share on your social media platform (tagging us, sharing the # & linking the campaign) 3. + send the video into us at soulseedgathering@gmail.com for us to share within our campaign video. Please add your social media handle in the email, for us to tag you back.If you are male-identifying you can still join by sharing and recording the line 'There Is More To Her Story' to camera, and still using the same #thereismoretoourstory and sending in to us!Thanks again!There Is More To Our Story & we have only just begun...

story:
C I T T A D I N O  

N E L                                                                                     

M O N D O

L O C A T I O N

CAMPAGNANO DI ROMA, ITALY

 

D A T E S   A N D   D U R A T I O N

 OCTOBER 22ND – NOVEMBER 20TH

 

ABOUT:

Cittadino Nel Mondo is an art collective and art residency program that hosts a small group of artists from around the world. Cittadino Nel Mondo residencies are 'pop-up residency's', created in different locations around the world from the far east like Japan to Italy and other locations. The founder of Cittadino Nel Mondo, Natalia Bieganska, is an artist who has travelled the world extensively and has been deeply inspired by local cultures. As a result of her travels, Natalia has a strong mission to connect artists from different countries and backgrounds. Art for her is a new language, universal in nature, breaking down any cultural differences.  

 

LOCATION:

This year's residency will take place in Italy, the birthplace of some of the most famous artists in history. 

The program will support the artist to disconnect from city life and work on their art in a warm and rustic setting in the Italian countryside.  The residency is based in the small village Campagnano di Roma, which is located roughly 45 minutes from Rome and easily accessible by car or train. Campagnano di Roma was on the Via Francigena in medieval times, an ancient road running from France to Rome. The area is filled with ancient Roman and Etruscan history; the energy of painters, sculptors and other makers of the past can almost be smelt in the air.

 

C O N C E P T: 

LEARNING ABOUT LOCAL SUSTAINABILITY: 

Each Cittadino Nel Mondo program implies a theme that fits well with the surrounding region and culture. Besides the creative aspect, a core mission of Cittadino Nel Mondo in Campagnano is to take care of nature by teaching artist about sustainability, raising awareness of the local environment, and the production of healthy local foods. Cittadino nel Mondo provides to the participants organic products of everyday use and promotes minimal waste living. Artists will participate and learn about organic olive oil farming and production from the local Italian family. 

 

 

O R G A N I Z E R S:

NATALIA BIEGANSKA

FOUNDER AND DIRECTOR

Natalia has been in the fashion and art world for the last 9 years. Most recently she worked at Postmasters Gallery in Rome. Prior to Rome, Natalia was living and studying in New York where she took Marketing and PR courses at Sotheby’s NYC.  Natalia has exhibited her work as an emerging artist in Japan, New York and Italy. Beforehand, she was working in high fashion for international agencies such as Elite and Next Models; and has experience working for some of the top brands including Vogue Magazine, D&G, and GAP. Natalia holds a BA from Wladyslaw Strzeminski Academy of Fine Arts in Lodz, Poland majoring in design in 2012. 

 

PAULINA BEBECKA

ADVISORY BOARD, SALES AND EVENTS

After 11 years as NYC gallerist at Postmasters Gallery (est. 1984) and curator the Polish born Paulina Bebecka moved to Rome in 2017 and established the Italian branch of the gallery, PostmastersROMA, with a permanent location situated next to the colosseum. Following the tradition of the mothership gallery the Roman space exhibits works that are representative of our time embracing all mediums, classical and new ones from paintings to Virtual Reality.  Her curatorial projects include a NYTimes reviewed exhibition “this one is smaller than this one” of 35 artists which traveled from New York to Vienna and Istanbul. Bebecka holds a masters degree from Sotheby’s Institute of Art in London and bachelors degrees in economics and international business administration from the American University of Paris.

 

ANITA BENN

Dipl. Shiatsu therapist (ISS) since 2009.

Anita Benn was born in a multicultural family in Switzerland. For various health issues of her loved ones she started looking deeper into alternative medicine. At age of 22 she travelled to India discovering Ayurveda and Yoga. Later Anita decided to broaden her horizons and chosen her school of life to be Shiatsu. Three years of education at the International Shiatsu School of Kinetal taught her, that while we are all responsible for our own body mind and soul, she is able to give her patients the support to activate the self-healing process.

 

A R T I S T S:

1. SIGNE PIERCE 

represented by Annka Kultys Gallery, London

Signe Pierce is a multimedia artist whose work straddles performance, photography, video, theory, social media, light design and installation.  As a self-described "reality artist", Pierce's work is inspired by the concept of reality being an artistic medium, and that an artist's life can be viewed within a similar context as an artist's work.  As a writer, performer, and theorist, she is known for using humor, seduction, technology, science and current events to unpack the various paradoxes of perception and existence within an increasingly simulated world, as well as working to discern what is considered "real" within a burgeoning era of technological singularity.

Over the last few years, Pierce has partaken in multiple performances, installations, screenings, and exhibitions, including solo shows at Times Square Space in New York, Annka Kultys Gallery in London, and Galerie Nathalie Halgand in Vienna, as well as a screening + performance at the Museum of Modern Art, US, and an artist's talks at Yale University, University of Colorado, and Southern Methodist University. She is the star and co-creator of the acclaimed short film, American Reflexxx, which has received multiple awards and has been screened in over 15 countries.

 

2. CANYON CASTATOR

represented by Postmasters Gallery, NYC

Castator's large-scale oil paintings bring us into a twisted version of today's social reality. Each is a gruesome, cartoon-like collage with graphically distorted figures, packed into vivid scenes of debauchery. By heightening what is already grotesque and salacious about party culture, substance abuse, harassment, and violence override the casual vice. The more disturbing the scenario, the more macabre its actors. This is a world of extremes, from the overloaded content to the work's strong narrative impulse to the bright and bold aesthetic that Castator never shies from.   

Digital processes give the work its copy-paste quality. Preparatory drawings are executed on an iPad, where compositional elements can be readily resized, moved, deleted, or restored. Imagery is often culled from personal or found photos. Exuberant patterns and a melange of textures, whether they are superflat or perspectivally perfect, commingle with humor and ease.

Canyon Castator (b. 1989) is a Los Angeles-based painter. In 2013, he was invited to be a resident at the Kunstakademie Düsseldorf, where he studied with Tal R. He is originally from Boulder, Colorado.

 

3. PIERO PASSACANTANDO

 Piero Passacantando (b. 1979) is an Italian interdisciplinary artist born in Rome. He paints, cooks, and conducts participatory workshops revolving around either painting or art of culinary. In the past ten years, his focus has shifted towards the possible connections between art and food. Piero trained, cooked and catered in various capacities around the United States and Europe. His food is influenced by his travels and offers a broad spectrum of flavors and approaches. In particular, the interaction of Italian, New American, Mexican, Indian, Caribbean and Vietnamese influences play a role in his creations.

Most recently, he has been developing Fomento Fermento. Between collaborative art project and cooking workshop, FF is a knowledge and cultural exchange revolving around fermentation. FF seeks to be informal, hands-on and fun; yet it aims to be informative and to discuss the science and history of fermentation. Through these workshops, Piero hopes to encourage connections between people - to foment the fermentation of love through magic, science, fun and exchange.

Among many art residencies he attended, he also performed his project “I Paint You. You Paint Me.” at Bric Arts, Ed Varie, the Brooklyn Museum, Art in Odd Places, DUMBO Arts Festival in NYC and in Mexico during the LILHA. Passacantando holds an MFA from the California College of the Arts (San Francisco and Oakland, CA) with a concentration in Social Practice, and a BFA from the Corcoran College of Art and Design (Washington DC). He lives and works in Rome, Italy, and New York City, USA.

 

 

 

B U D G E T:

 

ARTIST AIR TICKETS     4000 EUR

Two return tickets from USA.

 

CATERING     4000 EUR

Food, drinks, occasional dining, cook for 4-5 people for a month.

 

ACCOMMODATION AND CLEANING     3500 EUR

Exclusive access to entire property and all the houses.

  

BASIC ART SUPPLIES       500 EUR

Oversized canvas and frame to be stretched at the property.

 

OPEN STUDIOS AND COLLECTORS LUNCH     1500 EUR

Transport invited guests (collectors and gallery owners) from Rome to Campagnano and back, lunch - catering or chef, wine.

   

TRANSPORTATION     1000 EUR

 

PHOTO AND VIDEO DOCUMENTATION     3000 EUR

Professional photographer and videographer plus printing few copies of book which will contain documentation of month long program.

 

PR PERSON     2000 EUR

PR person responsible for press coverage, help with organizing and inviting collectors to the collectors lunch.

 

ORGANISERS FEES   10000 EUR

Shared between the organizers and additional staff/help during a month-long residency, budget for any additional expenses.

 

TOTAL 29 500 EUR

 

​* IF any funds will remain in the CNM budget, it will be used for next round of the program. Happening in Tokyo May/April 2020.
