That means receiving travelers in a place tailor made to fit their needs and coordinating with our partners to place them where their skills would be needed. We plan to equip them with the tools (machetes, chainsaws, gloves, etc.) that would allow them to be useful on site. In addition, we would provide transportation to and from volunteering sites, as well as to-go meals.
We are committed to making a self-sustainable space.
We would like to use the 775 square foot terrace of Casita Esperanza as a “huerto,” food garden. Through a rain collecting system, paired with a reverse osmosis water filtration, we’ll be able to collect water for the garden and provide drinkable water. Following an agro ecologic line, our garden is free of chemicals and able to produce diverse fruits and vegetables toward the consumption of our visitors. Finally, we wish to run on solar energy, severing the ties with inefficient and obsolete Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority.
We provide a space for our network.
We would like to provide our network of small organizations with not only volunteers but also a space to stay in Casita Esperanza and enjoy its ammenities when traveling to the metro area. The terrace would also be available for our network to host educational workshops and events.
 
Although Casita Esperanza is a fairly new project, it is past the theoretical stage.
We have the physical space, located in Punta Las Marias, Santurce. We have a website under construction and have started establishing relationships with international volunteers as well as the different local organizations. We are confident that this project has great potential, and we are looking forward to the support of our contributors to help us bring it to fruition.


Casita Esperanza, the vision!
 
About Us
Casita Esperanza stems from the collaboration between two friends, who moved to Puerto Rico, respectively, from France and from Texas, and decided to join forces in the wake of the aftermath of Hurricane Maria. Having worked and lived on the island for several years, we’ve developed strong ties to the community and are happy to call Puerto Rico our home.
The strength of this project comes from our diverse and complementary backgrounds. One of us is experienced in interior displays and was an integral part of the successful opening of Nordstrom on the island; while the other created and runs Sin Mirar Pa’l La’O (SMPL), a community based non-profit.
After the passage of Hurricane Maria, circumstances presented us with a dilemma. We could choose to leave to pursue opportunities outside of Puerto Rico, or to stay and try and make a positive impact. We easily settled on the latter, and this is how Casita Esperanza was born.

 
Where will your contributions go?
Along with the coordination, transportation, and work tools needed to be useful for volunteers, we would love to offer a volunteer friendly housing rate of $10 per night, instead of a $40 rate comparable to guest homes in the area, for people to stay at Casita Esperanza. We are thankful Puerto Rico is the perfect climate for growing vegetables on the terrace; furthermore, with the addition of gardening essentials, we can harvest our own food in a few months time. 
 
Your deeply appreciated support will assist us in making our vision of Casita Esperanza as an all-encompassing project a reality. This includes:
 -Volunteer ready work tools (chainsaws, machetes, rubber boots, work gloves, outdoor hats, etc.)
-Terrace food garden essentials (seeds, gardening tools, rain collector)
-Transportation and meal preparation costs
-Furniture
-Occupancy Rate (3 rooms booked for 3 months)
-Solar Energy Systems
 -Contributions past our goal will help Casita Esperanza with branding and advertising
 
Why back this project? 
You want to be a part of supporting Puerto Rico and it’s sustainable reconstruction after Hurricane Maria and there are rewards involved!
 
Other Ways You Can Help
We understand not everyone is able to donate to this project, however, sharing our campaign goes a long way. We thank you in advance for your support!
 
Risks & Challenges
Our biggest challenge right now is not having consistent central electric power. This complicates and slows down the work process. However, we are committed to keeping our contributors updated as much as we can along the way.

story:
Short Summary

 

Hi, my name is Michael Britton, and I’m the current director of the Bluefields Sound System community recording studio and multimedia Center, the first of it's kind on the south autonomous region of Nicaragua. I was born in Bluefields, Nicaragua and lived in the United States of America for over 15 years. Shortly after returning from the United States Marine Corps I returned to Bluefields, and what was supposed to be a 3 months trip to plant the seeds for a couple projects with a non-profit corporation I founded named “One Earth-One People-One Love Inc. (1EPL, Inc.) in the state of Georgia. Now I've been in Bluefields for 3 years, and each day since I came back, I’ve been learning more than I ever had. I came to know of the richness and uniqueness of our cultural heritage like never before, such as our Ethnic diversity, our traditional musical composition, and other artistic expressions that could have a major impact in our society.

In 2005, two young motivated Americans by the names of Edwin Reed and Alexander Scott, began promoting young talents and local artist from a generation that is being left in a distant memory for most, talents that were undervalued for decades. They managed to raise funds for their cause and were able to move our communities in ways they haven’t moved for nearly 30 years; Musical albums were produced,  archiving new and authentic content from artists like “papa Bantam, Kaliboom, Mango Ghost, Sabu the Catty man,” among others. Unfortunately, the Bluefields Sound System’s grand presentation began to fade as Edwin and Alexander began to face the difficulties of the challenges in sustainable cultural promotion on this region of the world; funds ran low, and financial difficulties forced them to go seeking for a space to relocate the studio. In attempt to execute a project in collaboration with the regional government, in 2012 the regional government of the South Autonomous Caribbean Coast or Nicaragua granted them a space in a building that was funded to have a community space, in which the only operation was a government owned radio station. They allowed BSS to work under our own bureaucracy, while respecting a basic operation schedule, and so the studio began producing once again, but this time it was more accessible for the general community, and not just selected local artists.

The project with the regional government suddenly discontinued due to unknown reasons, and within a year the only fully capacitated producer and musician had to leave in search for a better opportunity, so once again the studio faced the threat of closing. By this time Edwin had left and Alex was about to leave to study for his master’s degree, leaving a few motivated artists with no administrative knowledge to continue the operation of the studio. This is the point at which I began to volunteer at the Bluefields Sound System Studio. Shortly after I began, the challenges rose again, as members of the regional government began to make attempts to take over our equipment, and so force us to close our doors. we fought a two-year battle while serving our communities as an accessible resource that otherwise was not available in our region. We became part of the violence prevention committee in our region, we worked hand in hand with the regional youth secretary using information communication technology to promoted cultural awareness by executing projects that educated society of the richness and value of our cultural heritage, and the importance to advocate for a cleaner, safer, and more productive culture of peace. Unfortunately, we were forced to find another location, because government officials needed another office space. As a result, we were facing the threat of losing a couple of the computers that we have been using for over 5 years, which are among our most valuable resource to do our work. 

We managed to rent a suitable space that met the conditions for us to operate again as a community recording studio and multimedia center. Unfortunately, we were economically crippled by relocating. Our overhead cost for rent are more than we are able to generate having a limited staff that works on a volunteer basis. Over the past three years we have been designed a project based on our organization's operational model, of which with your support we can begin full operation of the project Caribbean Culture Center for Arts & Music by the end February of 2017. 

 

the following videos are samples among many other kinds of products that we will be producing...

 

 

 

 

· Why this initiative is important for me

Culture is the arts and other manifestations of human intellectual achievement regarded collectively. Culture can be viewed as characteristics and knowledge of a particular group of people, defined by everything from language, religion, cuisine, social habits, music and arts, and when those aspects of culture are being lost an inevitable unbalance occurs that cause changes that may alter land, customs, and even the people them selves will have to adapt and eventually lose valuable aspects of that culture. When the culture of a people has been the mechanism of survival for thousands of years, it is imperative . Therefor to promote a sustainable culture of peace, it is imperative to rescue and preserve those aspects of culture that are being lost in our region.

 

Music is an expressive art of a cultural identity of our people, the lack of infrastructure and resource has limited the practice of that art for over 3 decades, slowly disappearing that unique identity.

 

Operating as a Community Recording Studio & Multimedia Center, Bluefields Sound System is the first Community Center of it’s kind. We have been a resource for society since 2005. Our works are mainly in the areas of Communication, Culture, and Youth. We are here to rescue and preserve those cultural values...

The Bluefields Sound System's Caribbean Cultural Center for Arts and Music project is a participatory development initiative aimed at providing Technology, Communication, Media production training, Arts & Music as an innovative and sustainable solution for capacity building of cultural tourism in isolated and economically disadvantaged indigenous and Afro-descendent communities. 

 

What your contribution will help achieve:

On the Autonomous regions of Nicaragua there is an immense fountain of natural resources, including talented artistic youths. Your contribution will help the Bluefields Sound System community recording studio and multimedia center to successfully execute the CCCAM initiatives for a year period, which will directly employ 5 skilled and talented member of our society, at least 20 people will be employed through commission based collaboration, and over a hundred youths will be trained on how to promote their skills and talent in their corresponding market within the first 3 months. Your contributions will help promote the sustainable development of our communities; by securing a staff for a year, BSS will launch the CCCAM initiative at its capacity and within a year we will have the CCCAM initiative replicated and put into operation in collaboration with communal leaders in 5 different communities in our region, creating means for job opportunities and rescuing and preserving our cultural heritage.

 
 

Contributions will help activate all four components of the project:

 

BSS Community Recording Studio (the only recording studio of it's kind):

This is a community recording studio where members of our society have access to acquire new skills and develop new talent, and exercise their abilities while learning valuable life-skills through music writing, composition, and overall expressions.

It’s open for inspired artist and professional artist alike, and it’s equipped with all necessary tools to compose, produce, and promote their music.

The Bluefields School of Music (Caribbean cultural music school):

This is where we will provide traditional and non-traditional instrument and vocal lessons. Most of the historical education of our musical expressions will be taught here. Music teachers will be the last living legendaries of our traditional music. 

SunRise Drama Club (SunRise DC):

This is first drama/acting program of it's kind in over 30 years.

Participants will learn the art of drama and acting, and how to implement those skills to performing arts and cultural expression.

Innovative Tech-Center (ITC):                                                                                                                                                This is a Multimedia computer lab where participants will have access to ICT workshops, computer courses, marketing workshops, language learning courses, audio & video production courses, and access to global information of technology.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise funds to continue renting the space where we have rebuilt our studio and have began executing our programs and services to provide a financial support (honorarium) for our volunteers in the administrative and operational structure, funds to implement projects designed and ready for execution, and to refurbish or purchase equipment to successfully execute the Caribbean Culture Center for Arts & Music project. 

As a result of your contribution, we will assure to keep you updated throughout the year by providing you with a free registration to our newsletter, keeping our facebook page updated daily, we will send you postcards signed by local artists most recognized, we will provide access to free download codes to download our latest productions, and also we will dedicate activities and  initiatives to donors among other perks. 

If we reach our goal, we will fully operate as a caribbean Cultural Center for Arts & Music; of which will have direct presence in 5 communities on the Caribbean Coast of Nicaragua.

 

The Impact

In economically disadvantaged communities across the globe, it is difficult or nearly impossible to gain access to resources that may simplify or simply give a chance to community members to augment the efforts to better the conditions in their communities. Bluefields Sound System, through the CCCAM initiatives is making available the resources that help community members of the South Autonomous Region of Nicaragua to market their artistic resources.  Music is transcendent, and the messages in music can influence emotional states and behavior, and as local artist get a fear chance to project their music to the world, it may be the song of one of them that touches you in a moment most necessary. The musical composition in our region is more than just music, it's the only way in which we record our history, because in our music, we tell current events and talk about people or places most influential in our communities. Having the studio's doors open is as having a system that will archive our history. Because we teach multimedia production, we have the initiative to begin producing the first visual productions in our region by people of our region. We will be countering most negative influence brought in through media, with positive influence from our reality.

In the past we have executed many projects, one of our most successful  project was the production of an album from the Bluefields school of Music, which was a byproduct of the first music school of it's kind in Bluefields since more than 30 years ago. The album featured legendary artist from the 70’s and 80’s and young artist of this generation in attempt to bridge a connection that can rescue our traditional music with this generation. We fundraised to print the album on Kickstarter and were funded more than 100% of our goal for that project.

Another one of our success have been in the late 2014… May of 2014, we hosted an initiative that promoted a cultural exchange between a reggae band from the New Mexico and our local Maypole Music. The project was executed in the form of a competition between young artist of the coast, whom had to compose new verses to accompany the chorus of our traditional maypole music from the 70’s as an attempt to once again bridge that generational gap in our traditional musical composition. The top 3 winners of the competition were granted the opportunity to participate in 3 concerts in three isolated communities on the South Autonomous region of Nicaragua, accompanied by the reggae band Reviva. A CD album was also produced from this event, the album contained the songs of all the participating local artist. The impact of this event is still resounding on the streets of Bluefields today as community members pass you by with their event shirt on and as the music is played on the radios in the month of celebration every may. By the end of our first year we will have developed a community network between islated indigenous and Afro-descendants in the South Autonomous Region of the Caribbean coast of Nicaragua Nicaragua

This video was made by one of SIT study abroad student visit to the Bluefields Sound System Studios in early 2016. The only inaccurate 
 

Risks & Challenges

We have been faced with many challenges, but we never gave up, and we will never give up. Our organization worked on "zero" funding for years. All of our teem members are volunteers working for a cause. We sustained ourselves providing professional services in the areas that we were teaching. unfortunately that was not a steady stream of income to maintain a full staff to operate according to our full capacity, and that have been our greatest challenge in the past. Especially since the government had limited us to a work schedule that only allowed us to provide free community service, leaving us with no time for our sustainability model to be executed. 

If we were to reach our goal in this fund raiser, the main challenge we will face is the fact that we will be limited to the number of communities in which we will have a presence during the first year. There is a high demand for our presence in all of our communities, unfortunately there is hardly any support and when available, it's minimal, but they are willing to work with us once we have the financial support to back up our projects.

 

 
 

The Rhythm of Our Culture short documentary

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Just by reading this information you have contributed, because this organization is a social work most needed in our communities and across the globe. If you were able to contribute, we thank you tremendously, and if you were not able to contribute economically, or by donating equipments, we ask you to please don't forget to use the Indiegoogo share tools!

Spread the news!!!

story:
A Message From DJ Stormin Norman:

I love playing music for people. I love playing music that makes people dance. I love playing music that makes people dance and has people come together. This is why I’ve been a DJ for the people for 30 years. My heart is with the people that make up my beloved community of Harlem. That’s why 11 years ago I created Sundae Sermon. I wanted the people of my community to have a free, family-friendly outdoor party and picnic where they felt free to dance, picnic, play, laugh, come out and connect with each other. All with a backdrop of good music that makes us happy while keeping us healthy.

The people came, first by the hundreds, then by the thousands. The people came, with their children, parents, partners and friends. They came with their blankets and BBQ.

It was beautifully fulfilling to see thousands of people from all over gathered and having free fun, but then came the obstacles. I've been working relentlessly to overcome the lofty and costly problems associated with trying to maintain and protect “Good Music For Good People”. This should continue to be a gift for the good people and take place in  parks within the village of Harlem. 

I was downtrodden and discouraged. What lifted and fueled me was the peoples cry . Reading newspaper articles asking "What happened to Sundae Sermon?" The constant emails from all over the world and the disappointment on the faces of the parishioners who asked "Why weren't there any Sundae Sermon in 2016? What can I/we do? We need Sundae Sermon!"  This reminded me of why I created it and gave me a renewed energy.  It was hurtful not having the answers, it was a really hard time for me. I missed my people.  I made a declaration that amidst the times we are living through LOVE is STRONGER! The People of Harlem are Strong! #harlemstrong SUNDAE SERMON IS BACK .  

Amen! 

Sundae Sermon is proudly participating with  Harlem Week

Sunday, August 11th @ St. Nicholas Park on 135th Street 1PM-6PM! 

SUNDAE SERMON NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT, NOW!


“Staying Strong & Happy through Music, Dance & Community”

It has always been my vision to keep Sundae Sermon free. In lieu of time constraints we were unable to secure corporate sponsorships or grants for this series. We need to raise money FAST to pay for production costs. So I’m coming to you, I’m counting on you, The People, to please support. Any amount helps. 

Investing in Sundae Sermon is investing in CULTURE.

We all love Harlem and what it represents. We all deserve this day of healthy happiness Sundae Sermon creates. The services that make that happiness happen have costs associated with sound, DJs, permits, talent and more. Your generous support will also help us set up the Sundae Sermon Foundation so we can invest in the happiness our community throughout the year.

Invest in Sundae Sermon:

For The Love of Good People. For The Love of Good Music.

For The Love of Beloved Community. For The Love of Strong Family.

For The Love of Our History. For The Love of How We Dance.

For The Love of Our Culture. For The Love of Our Future.

Invest in Sundae Sermon For The Love Of Harlem! 

You can see more about our event and the communal joy we are promoting at http://sundaesermon.com

 

                          ** Special appreciation to our community sponsors and supporters **                          New York Dept of Parks and Recreation, Frederick Douglass Blvd Association, Whole Foods, Red Rooster, UPTOWN Magazine and Harlem Park to Park 

 

Cheers, 

  DJ Stormin Norman

 

 

 

​​

I love playing music for people. I love playing music that makes people dance. I love playing music that makes people dance and has people come together. This is why I’ve been a DJ for the people for 30 years. My heart is with the people that make up my beloved community of Harlem. That’s why 11 years ago I created Sundae Sermon. I wanted the people of my community to have a free, family-friendly outdoor party and picnic where they felt free to dance, picnic, play, laugh, come out and connect with each other. All with a backdrop of good music that makes us happy while keeping us healthy.
The people came, first by the hundreds, then by the thousands. The people came, with their children, parents, partners and friends. They came with their blankets and BBQ.
It was beautifully fulfilling to see thousands of people from all over gathered and having free fun, but then came the obstacles. I've been working relentlessly to overcome the lofty and costly problems associated with trying to maintain and protect “Good Music For Good People”. This should continue to be a gift for the good people and take place in  parks within the village of Harlem. 
I was downtrodden and discouraged. What lifted and fueled me was the peoples cry . Reading newspaper articles asking "What happened to Sundae Sermon?" The constant emails from all over the world and the disappointment on the faces of the parishioners who asked "Why weren't there any Sundae Sermon in 2016? What can I/we do? We need Sundae Sermon!"  This reminded me of why I created it and gave me a renewed energy.  It was hurtful not having the answers, it was a really hard time for me. I missed my people.  I made a declaration that amidst the times we are living through LOVE is STRONGER! The People of Harlem are Strong! #harlemstrong SUNDAE SERMON IS BACK .  
Amen! 
Sundae Sermon is proudly participating with  Harlem Week
Sunday, August 11th @ St. Nicholas Park on 135th Street 1PM-6PM! 
SUNDAE SERMON NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT, NOW!
“Staying Strong & Happy through Music, Dance & Community”
It has always been my vision to keep Sundae Sermon free. In lieu of time constraints we were unable to secure corporate sponsorships or grants for this series. We need to raise money FAST to pay for production costs. So I’m coming to you, I’m counting on you, The People, to please support. Any amount helps. 
Investing in Sundae Sermon is investing in CULTURE.
We all love Harlem and what it represents. We all deserve this day of healthy happiness Sundae Sermon creates. The services that make that happiness happen have costs associated with sound, DJs, permits, talent and more. Your generous support will also help us set up the Sundae Sermon Foundation so we can invest in the happiness our community throughout the year.
Invest in Sundae Sermon:
For The Love of Good People. For The Love of Good Music.
For The Love of Beloved Community. For The Love of Strong Family.
For The Love of Our History. For The Love of How We Dance.
For The Love of Our Culture. For The Love of Our Future.
Invest in Sundae Sermon For The Love Of Harlem! 
You can see more about our event and the communal joy we are promoting at http://sundaesermon.com
 
                          ** Special appreciation to our community sponsors and supporters **                          New York Dept of Parks and Recreation, Frederick Douglass Blvd Association, Whole Foods, Red Rooster, UPTOWN Magazine and Harlem Park to Park 
 
Cheers, 
  DJ Stormin Norman
 
 
 
​​

story:
My name is Benjamin Mathes, I was inspired to create Urban Confessional because I experienced the healing power of LISTENING in my own life. I felt compelled to share it with as many people as possible.

One day I was walking down the street and a homeless man asked for money. I turned to him and offered to LISTEN instead. I saw how the simple act of listening was not only a gift to him but a gift to me, in that moment we were both restored. A few days later along with a group of friends, we decided to walk over to a nearby train station and hold up signs that read FREE LISTENING. We stood there and just LISTENED, truly LISTENED to strangers tell us whatever they wanted to tell us. It was a judgment-free zone, the experience was magical and that's how URBAN CONFESSIONAL was born.

Fast forward 5 years and the Urban Confessional movement has reached over 70 countries and thousands of volunteers.

Our goal with this campaign is to raise enough funds to reach even more people. To date, I have been paying for the cost of running URBAN CONFESSIONAL on my own which is limiting. In order to grow the movement and be able to affect more people around the world, it's imperative that we raise more funds.

The money will go toward covering the costs of running the website, social media, marketing, organizing Free Listening days around the world, as well as creating a podcast, free online training in multiple languages, multi-lingual downloadable training materials, and creating live events around the world that will bring communities together and help spread the message and practice of non-judgmental compassionate listening. 

 

URBAN CONFESSIONAL started with a small group of committed volunteers, in a sense, it was created by the community it has benefited. By growing the community we will be able to bring the healing power of listening to anyone and everyone who's willing to be a part of our community.

Your contributions are highly appreciated. Any amount (And I mean any) makes a big difference. Also please take a moment to share this campaign with your own community.

Thank you for taking the time to visit this page and for taking a stand for listening.  I picture a day in which we can embrace our differences, put aside our judgement and learn to just be with each other.  

 

 

Below are some of the perks we're offering:

story:
<<<  CAMPAIGN UPDATES  >>>

Every donation given means a lot to us, it insures sustainability to the bookshop and our dear Travelling Bookshop "Nancy".

Few days are left for the campaign period and I'm Blessed by the support of my friends and Kawon's spreading community, I have a strong belief in all of you, Thank you so much :)

Cultural Trip has just published an amazing article about "Kawon" and "Books on the Road", please share it with everyone you know :)

 

Being the first bookshop in town is not enough. Here's the story of Kawon:

In the beginning of 2016, the idea of Kawon was born. The fledgling idea emerged from the heart of the community for the need of change in our society, to make people more familiar with the benefit of reading through self–learning methods and social activities.

Kawon started as self-funded project. After facing financial stress, Kawon launched a social street initiative called “Books On the Road” to help fund the project in Madaba, Jordan.

Books on the Road involves displaying books on a 1974 Mercedes 200 called "Nancy." Making a unique signature on people passing by, Books On the Road has gained local and international interests and has became one of Amman’s main attractions. 

We have finally opened our bookshop in Madaba and have been operating since December 2, 2016.

Learn more about Books on the Road and me at Stories of Our City. 

**The Project**             

Kawon is a socially-active bookstore, a cultural space for youth in Madaba, Jordan, with a friendly environment that encourages reading culture through social engagement activities. 

Our mission: To spread reading culture through an interactive approach by committing to engage with the many diverse people and organizations of our community and to provide good quality books of all types at affordable prices. Additionally, we strive to provide a hospitable and nurturing environment to encourage the healthy exchange of ideas.

Our vision: Nurturing the life of the mind through our products, services, and experiences.

 

**Our Campaign**  

Asking for 50,000 dollars might be a little challenging! That's why I wanna tell you where the campaign money will go and how it will be spent. 

First, to launch our "Books On the Road" campaign around the twelve cities of Jordan we need to transform "Nancy the car."  That includes some body work and the visual identify of the car and adding a caravan/trailer that stores a good amount of books. We also need to fix the mechanics and engine of Nancy to enable me to travel long distances to villages and remote areas where I can deliver books to kids and young people for free to be part of the bookshop's community service.

Second, expanding the bookshop in Madaba will need a lot of work:

- Restoring and preserving the extension of the ancient building we currently occupy. 

- Fixing the infrastructure of the building.

- Building bathrooms for people to use.

- Installing water tanks and plumbing.

- Improving our electrical grid (renewable energy).

Third, fixing the Eco Garden behind the bookshop for people to engage in and enjoy: to sit and read and get creative.

Fourth and finally, free books aren't free! We will need to continually buy a good amount of books to be distributed to kids and young people to spread reading culture throughout Jordan, even in the hard-to-reach places! 

Other ways you can help:

- You can help out by sending us used books to P.O. Box 745 Madaba 17110, Jordan.

- Link us to an NGO or a foundation for grant recommendations.

- Get involved with us through your work (e.g. consulting, business planning, etc.).

* Please don't hesitate to send us an email at ghaith-kawon@outlook.com

Links

https://web.facebook.com/kawonofficial/

https://www.instagram.com/kawon_official/

Special thanks to Scott Lashinsky for making this campaign possible :) 

scott@storiesofourcity.org

story:
Welcome to Transmission Ministry Collective!

Sometimes you wanna go where everybody knows—and uses—your name! For transgender and gender-expansive people in faith communities, this can be a tall order. People in our church may refuse to use our right name and pronouns, or we may be forced out of our community for coming out or for transitioning. We’re often asked to choose between our identity and our faith, or to make part of ourselves invisible so we can fit in.

At Transmission Ministry Collective, we’re a Christian organization created by trans folks, for trans folks, and we’re imagining a different kind of community—one that celebrates the wholeness of every person, and makes space for the unique gifts gender-expansive people bring to the table.

Transmission Ministry Collective is an online community dedicated to the spiritual care, faith formation, and leadership potential of transgender, nonbinary, and gender-expansive Christians. We provide Bible studies, support groups, prayer and meditation sessions, a chat server, and more, all for free, and with online workshops on theology and gender offered on a pay-as-you-can basis.

As an organization we’ve launched at a critical time in history, when connection and compassion are more important than ever. Over the past month, we’ve doubled the number of groups and events we hold each week to keep up with the need for support expressed by our community. The number of individuals in each group has also doubled as people seek meaning and comfort in a space that they know will be protected and faith-centered.

We need your help to keep this community going—and growing—in the months ahead. We have big plans to launch new groups for family members of gender-expansive folks, for trans pastors and people in seminary, and for trans people of color. And we plan to expand our online workshop offerings so that interactive and inclusive theology can be accessible to everyone!

We want to invite you to partner with us in this important work. Whether you can give $1 or $1,000, your support is bringing about a world where more people can feel whole, seen, and loved for who they are. Thank you for becoming part of our community.

Where Your Donation Goes, and What You Get

When you partner with TMC, your gifts go directly to funding the work we’re doing over the coming months as we launch and respond to the COVID-19 emergency. Because we’re an online community our overhead costs are low, and our expenses consist mostly of communication software and the wages paid to our staff and community leaders. We believe that everyone deserves to be paid fairly for their labor, especially people from marginalized communities who are often underpaid and undervalued. TMC is committed to paying our staff and contractors a $20 per hour minimum wage for their work. We’re so thankful for the group leaders, Bible study facilitators, educators, chat moderators, organizers, and board members for all that they do to make this space possible.

In return for partnering with us on this journey, we’d like to send you a thank-you gift! We’re especially excited to unveil our exclusive TMC launch t-shirts and stickers, with a design by Karsen Gromm, a member of the TMC community.

In this time of social distancing, you might also find some joy in a letter in your mailbox, or a chat over coffee or tea with one of the TMC staff members, or even a lifetime pass to every TMC online workshop! Check the perks menu to find out more about all of the amazing options. No matter how you choose to support this community, we’d like to thank you.

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course, many people are dealing with economic stress and may not be able to support TMC financially. If this is where you are right now, we get it, and we’re still so thankful for your enthusiasm. You can still help to support our vision of trans-inclusive Christian community by sharing this fundraiser via social media, or by signing up for our community newsletter so that you can keep in touch as we grow.

Plus, if you know someone who would be interested in joining in on any of the events and groups we run, feel free to send them our way! You can always find us online at the following links.

Our website: https://www.transmissionministry.com/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/transmissionministry
Twitter: https://www.twitter.com/TransmissionMin
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/TransmissionMinistryCollective
Instagram: @TransmissionMinistry

story:
“It’s always heartening to see young people be the bridge, whether they are from the US or from South Africa. It was my dad that said the youth are our future. We have to make sure the youth are properly educated and trained. And it is through education and exposure to other people, through sharing that we learn and we better understand ourselves.”

-Dr. Makaziwe Mandela

 

“Being in this program actually helped cultivate what I wanted to do. I knew engineering was something that I always planned. But, being in Africa and working with these students and really being exposed to STEM and all the technological things that they did. It really helped me see that I wanted to do this for a career.”

-Djeder Basu, student at UMBC College of Engineering

 

“Swaliga is on the cutting edge of a culturally responsible social innovation that clearly activates intrinsic motivation in students and positions them in the pipeline of emerging global citizens”

- Kwabena Boateng, Chair of the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Africa Homecoming

Background: The Challenge and Opportunity

Since 2012, the Swaliga Foundation has been providing STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Math) education through after-school programs, cultural exchange programs, and original online content to its youth in Washington, D.C. Over the years, we have identified three important trends in STEAM and education:

  • Lack of diversity in STEAM fields. This exam by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) also reports that “disadvantaged students remain significantly less likely than their advantaged peers to see themselves pursuing a career in [STEM].”
  • Opportunities for STEAM jobs rising. Careers in these STEAM fields are projected to account for 70% of job growth by the year 2020 totaling over a million new jobs (National Science Foundation).
  • Diversity in STEAM signals huge benefits to tech innovation. Diversity matters.  More and more we are understanding why. For example, according to a University of Maryland and Columbia Business School joint study, gender diversity at the management level leads to a $42 million increase in value of S&P 500 firms.

So how do we improve diversity in STEAM? Over the past seven years, we found our most successful program helps solve this question. We call this program #STEAMtheBlock.

 

Meet #STEAMtheBlock

#STEAMtheBlock uses digital art as a bridge to teach Engineering Design and Applied Science. Since 2012 Swaliga Foundation has worked with more than 8,000 youth from the lowest income communities in the DC metro region proving afterschool programming, cultural exchange programs and community workshops at little or no cost to families. In a recent workshop series at McKinley Tech Middle School in Washington, D.C., provided through a grant award from the DC Commission on the Arts & Humanities, Swaliga’s #STEAMtheBlock curriculum resulted in an 87% increase in comprehension in Engineering and Science concepts.

Swaliga’s #STEAMtheBlock program focuses on three main goals:

  • Increase student efficacy in STEAM
  • Boost youth engagement in STEAM through digital arts
  • Build awareness of STEAM related fields

Swaliga uses the arts during STEM instruction in ways that are not seen in traditional school settings. Through creativity and music, students actively engage in learning STEM regardless of learning styles, background or socioeconomic status. The ultimate reward for students who successfully complete the #STEAMtheBlock program is to travel with Swaliga during the STEAM Cultural Exchange, which brings us to why we are here at Indiegogo!

 

The Experience of a Lifetime: The #STEAMtheBlock Cultural Exchange Trip

Our goal is to raise funds to host 7 South African students in our hometown of Washington, D.C.

#STEAMtheBlock culminates in the #STEAMtheBlock Cultural Exchange trip at the end of the school year. Launched in 2016, the trip has sent students and educators from the United States to South Africa to engage with their peers in cultural dialogue and interactive STEAM educational workshops. This week-long international youth summit consists of more than 35 hours of educational programming, as well as a community service project.

2019 will be the first year that our cultural exchange will take place in Washington, DC. In this week-long international youth summit rooted in STEAM, Health & Wellness, and Entrepreneurship & Leadership, seven South African students will join their peers from Washington D.C. and Houston to visit universities, attend workshops and panel discussions, and spend time together enjoying the arts and culture of DC. In total, about 30 exchange students will be participating.

Our community service project will be aimed directly at youth homelessness in Washington, D.C. As with every year, the exchange will culminate in our 4th annual #STEAMtheBlock party on July 27, 2019.

Example Itinerary for the #STEAMtheBlock Cultural Exchange Trip

Day 6, Monday, 22 July 2019 at Howard University   

  • 8:00 am, Breakfast
  • 8:45 am, Depart from home for Global Transcendence
  • 9:30 am, Health & Wellness - Guided meditation, affirmations, and yoga
  • 9:45 am, Team building and cultural exchange
  • 10:00 am, Welcome from city officials, founders, and partners
  • 11:30 am, Arrival at Howard University
  • 12:00 pm, Lunch
  • 1:00 pm, Global education discussion
  • 1:45 pm, Musical performance
  • 2:15 pm, Howard University campus tour with students and alumni
  • 3:15 pm, Depart from Howard University
  • 3:30 pm, Arrive at Inclusive Innovation Incubator
  • 4:00 pm, Creative entrepreneurship panel with local businesses
  • 4:45 pm, #STEAMtheBlock Workshop – Computer Science
  • 6:00 pm, Event wrap up; depart for dinner
  • 6:30 pm, Arrive at Bukom Café

 

What Have We Done So Far?

Since 2016, the Swaliga Foundation has hosted three consecutive cultural exchange trips. In three years, we have grown this exchange from only two students and three educators from Washington, D.C. to an international program with participation reaching 50 students and 20 educators from Los Angeles, CA; Houston, TX; Atlanta, GA; along with Johannesburg, Cape Town, and Durban, South Africa. Together with our organizational partners, we formed the Global Education Exchange Coalition (GEEC) to plan, coordinate, and execute the cultural exchange.

For this year’s trip, we have established partnerships in DC and abroad to reduce to travel costs for our students as well as enhance their program experience. We have the following partnerships so far:

  • DMV Black Restaurant Week to afford lunch and dinner expenses
  • Ethiopian Airlines to assist with flight expenses
  • Embassy of the Republic of South Africa in Washington, DC support
  • Howard University providing student tours, facilities, and lunch
  • Georgetown University providing student tours, facilities, and lunch

 

How Your Support Will Be Used

Here is the breakdown of our budget:

Meals: $700

Covers breakfast for 10 days at $10 per meal for the 7 students. Lunch and dinner will be provided by our meal sponsor DMV Black Restaurant Week.

Flights: $5,000 to 10,500

Covers round trip flights from Johannesburg, South Africa to Washington, D.C. Each ticket costs between about $800 and $1,750. To be conservative we are budgeting for the high cost.

Lodging: $3000 to $4,200

Includes lodging for 10 nights in Washington, D.C. for 7 students. Lodging costs between $45 and $60 per night.

Ground Transportation: $4,000

Two 15-person vans for ground transportation around Washington, D.C. and airport drop off and pick up. The vans are for all of the exchange students.

 

What Will Happen Next

June

  • Campaign soft-launch, June 5
  • Official campaign launch, June 11
  • Purchase flights and secure lodging for exchange students

July

  • Fundraising complete, July 5
  • South Africa students arrive in Washington, D.C., July 20
  • STEAM Cultural Exchange, July 22 to 26
  • #STEAMtheBlock Party, July 27
  • South Africa students return home, July 29

 

Risks and Challenges

Although the Swaliga Foundation has successfully delivered the STEAM Cultural Exchange for the past three years, there are two primary risks that could endanger this year’s program: Airplane ticket prices and visas for the South African students. As we get closer to the date of the trip, airplane tickets will rise dramatically. We have accounted for this in our budget, however, there is still a chance that the ticket prices could exceed our estimated cost. Currently, the South African students are securing their visas. There is a rigorous interview process conducted by the US State Department that costs approximately $300 per person, yet does not guarantee entry into the country. Therefore, there is a chance that these students may not get their visas in time for the trip, which can reduce the number of students who can attend. We are currently working with the students to overcome the financial and temporal challenges associated with obtaining visas.

 

Credits

About the Swaliga Foundation

Lemond Brown, Founder and CEO of the Swaliga Foundation

The Swaliga Foundation is “Engineering the Art of Education” by providing quality STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Math) education to youth. Swaliga provides after-school programs, cultural exchange programs, and engaging STEAM content online. Our mission is to cultivate learning globally and inspire young people to connect their passion to successful careers.

Since 2012, Swaliga has impacted more than 8,000 young people across the world in 11 countries and 5 continents. During the 2018-19 school year Swaliga directly serves an average of 100 learners per week at 8 schools/community centers across the Washington, DC Metro region, in addition to providing free community events throughout the year. Based on formative evaluation surveys of Swaliga students, 95% say their confidence in Math & Science increased, 98% learned how to apply the Engineering Design process and improved their critical thinking skills.

The Swaliga Foundation is a federally recognized 501(c)(3) non-profit educational organization based in Washington, D.C.

A brief history of the Swaliga Foundation:

  • September 2012: Swaliga Foundation is founded in Washington, DC, USA
  • August 2013: Swaliga's #STEAMtheBlock™ Program Launches at Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Washington after school
  • March 2014: Swaliga partners with DC Public Schools to bring STEAM programming to the city’s youth during school time
  • June 2015: Swaliga Foundation receives 501(c)(3) tax-exempt status and launches a STEAM partnership with the Best Buy Foundation
  • July 2016: Swaliga launches its STEAM Cultural Exchange program bringing a group of 2 students and 3 educators from DC to South Africa; founded the Global Education Exchange Coalition (GEEC), a collaboration consisting of non-profit organizations and universities
  • July 2017: Swaliga brings a group 5 students and 3 educators from DC to South Africa connecting with schools and universities near Johannesburg and Cape Town.
  • July 2018: Swaliga leads the STEAM Cultural Exchange bringing more than 50 students and 20 educators from across the United States, including Houston, TX; Nashville, TN; and Los Angeles, CA. GEEC joins Swaliga in Johannesburg, South Africa to participate in a community service project that brings solar-powered lamps to 100 families without electricity living in Kliptown, Soweto, South Africa.
story_txt:
“It’s always heartening to see young people be the bridge, whether they are from the US or from South Africa. It was my dad that said the youth are our future. We have to make sure the youth are properly educated and trained. And it is through education and exposure to other people, through sharing that we learn and we better understand ourselves.”
-Dr. Makaziwe Mandela
 
“Being in this program actually helped cultivate what I wanted to do. I knew engineering was something that I always planned. But, being in Africa and working with these students and really being exposed to STEM and all the technological things that they did. It really helped me see that I wanted to do this for a career.”
-Djeder Basu, student at UMBC College of Engineering
 
“Swaliga is on the cutting edge of a culturally responsible social innovation that clearly activates intrinsic motivation in students and positions them in the pipeline of emerging global citizens”
- Kwabena Boateng, Chair of the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Africa Homecoming
Background: The Challenge and Opportunity

Since 2012, the Swaliga Foundation has been providing STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Math) education through after-school programs, cultural exchange programs, and original online content to its youth in Washington, D.C. Over the years, we have identified three important trends in STEAM and education:


Lack of diversity in STEAM fields. This exam by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) also reports that “disadvantaged students remain significantly less likely than their advantaged peers to see themselves pursuing a career in [STEM].”


Opportunities for STEAM jobs rising. Careers in these STEAM fields are projected to account for 70% of job growth by the year 2020 totaling over a million new jobs (National Science Foundation).

Diversity in STEAM signals huge benefits to tech innovation. Diversity matters.  More and more we are understanding why. For example, according to a University of Maryland and Columbia Business School joint study, gender diversity at the management level leads to a $42 million increase in value of S&P 500 firms.

So how do we improve diversity in STEAM? Over the past seven years, we found our most successful program helps solve this question. We call this program #STEAMtheBlock.
 
Meet #STEAMtheBlock

#STEAMtheBlock uses digital art as a bridge to teach Engineering Design and Applied Science. Since 2012 Swaliga Foundation has worked with more than 8,000 youth from the lowest income communities in the DC metro region proving afterschool programming, cultural exchange programs and community workshops at little or no cost to families. In a recent workshop series at McKinley Tech Middle School in Washington, D.C., provided through a grant award from the DC Commission on the Arts & Humanities, Swaliga’s #STEAMtheBlock curriculum resulted in an 87% increase in comprehension in Engineering and Science concepts.
Swaliga’s #STEAMtheBlock program focuses on three main goals:

Increase student efficacy in STEAM
Boost youth engagement in STEAM through digital arts
Build awareness of STEAM related fields

Swaliga uses the arts during STEM instruction in ways that are not seen in traditional school settings. Through creativity and music, students actively engage in learning STEM regardless of learning styles, background or socioeconomic status. The ultimate reward for students who successfully complete the #STEAMtheBlock program is to travel with Swaliga during the STEAM Cultural Exchange, which brings us to why we are here at Indiegogo!
 
The Experience of a Lifetime: The #STEAMtheBlock Cultural Exchange Trip

Our goal is to raise funds to host 7 South African students in our hometown of Washington, D.C.
#STEAMtheBlock culminates in the #STEAMtheBlock Cultural Exchange trip at the end of the school year. Launched in 2016, the trip has sent students and educators from the United States to South Africa to engage with their peers in cultural dialogue and interactive STEAM educational workshops. This week-long international youth summit consists of more than 35 hours of educational programming, as well as a community service project.
2019 will be the first year that our cultural exchange will take place in Washington, DC. In this week-long international youth summit rooted in STEAM, Health & Wellness, and Entrepreneurship & Leadership, seven South African students will join their peers from Washington D.C. and Houston to visit universities, attend workshops and panel discussions, and spend time together enjoying the arts and culture of DC. In total, about 30 exchange students will be participating.
Our community service project will be aimed directly at youth homelessness in Washington, D.C. As with every year, the exchange will culminate in our 4th annual #STEAMtheBlock party on July 27, 2019.
Example Itinerary for the #STEAMtheBlock Cultural Exchange Trip
Day 6, Monday, 22 July 2019 at Howard University   

8:00 am, Breakfast
8:45 am, Depart from home for Global Transcendence
9:30 am, Health & Wellness - Guided meditation, affirmations, and yoga
9:45 am, Team building and cultural exchange
10:00 am, Welcome from city officials, founders, and partners
11:30 am, Arrival at Howard University
12:00 pm, Lunch
1:00 pm, Global education discussion
1:45 pm, Musical performance
2:15 pm, Howard University campus tour with students and alumni
3:15 pm, Depart from Howard University
3:30 pm, Arrive at Inclusive Innovation Incubator
4:00 pm, Creative entrepreneurship panel with local businesses
4:45 pm, #STEAMtheBlock Workshop – Computer Science
6:00 pm, Event wrap up; depart for dinner
6:30 pm, Arrive at Bukom Café

 
What Have We Done So Far?

Since 2016, the Swaliga Foundation has hosted three consecutive cultural exchange trips. In three years, we have grown this exchange from only two students and three educators from Washington, D.C. to an international program with participation reaching 50 students and 20 educators from Los Angeles, CA; Houston, TX; Atlanta, GA; along with Johannesburg, Cape Town, and Durban, South Africa. Together with our organizational partners, we formed the Global Education Exchange Coalition (GEEC) to plan, coordinate, and execute the cultural exchange.
For this year’s trip, we have established partnerships in DC and abroad to reduce to travel costs for our students as well as enhance their program experience. We have the following partnerships so far:


DMV Black Restaurant Week to afford lunch and dinner expenses
Ethiopian Airlines to assist with flight expenses
Embassy of the Republic of South Africa in Washington, DC support
Howard University providing student tours, facilities, and lunch
Georgetown University providing student tours, facilities, and lunch

 
How Your Support Will Be Used

Here is the breakdown of our budget:
Meals: $700
Covers breakfast for 10 days at $10 per meal for the 7 students. Lunch and dinner will be provided by our meal sponsor DMV Black Restaurant Week.
Flights: $5,000 to 10,500
Covers round trip flights from Johannesburg, South Africa to Washington, D.C. Each ticket costs between about $800 and $1,750. To be conservative we are budgeting for the high cost.
Lodging: $3000 to $4,200
Includes lodging for 10 nights in Washington, D.C. for 7 students. Lodging costs between $45 and $60 per night.
Ground Transportation: $4,000
Two 15-person vans for ground transportation around Washington, D.C. and airport drop off and pick up. The vans are for all of the exchange students.
 
What Will Happen Next
June

Campaign soft-launch, June 5
Official campaign launch, June 11
Purchase flights and secure lodging for exchange students

July

Fundraising complete, July 5
South Africa students arrive in Washington, D.C., July 20
STEAM Cultural Exchange, July 22 to 26
#STEAMtheBlock Party, July 27
South Africa students return home, July 29

 
Risks and Challenges
Although the Swaliga Foundation has successfully delivered the STEAM Cultural Exchange for the past three years, there are two primary risks that could endanger this year’s program: Airplane ticket prices and visas for the South African students. As we get closer to the date of the trip, airplane tickets will rise dramatically. We have accounted for this in our budget, however, there is still a chance that the ticket prices could exceed our estimated cost. Currently, the South African students are securing their visas. There is a rigorous interview process conducted by the US State Department that costs approximately $300 per person, yet does not guarantee entry into the country. Therefore, there is a chance that these students may not get their visas in time for the trip, which can reduce the number of students who can attend. We are currently working with the students to overcome the financial and temporal challenges associated with obtaining visas.

story:
The best kinds of opportunities that we can offer to young people are opportunities in which they are doing actual work, hands-on opportunities that are conducive to creativity, free expression, and real-world experience. These opportunities, of course, are hard to come by. Especially among vulnerable populations, opportunities like these – which can lead to tremendous advancement in society – are often scarce to the point of invisibility.

At Speak&Do, we are hard at work launching our content creation initiative, through which we will develop videos for YouTube and podcast shows. We have built up a strong network of influencers, journalists, and other professionals, and we will draw on that network for our content. We will introduce young people to the world of media production, provide workshops, talks, run courses with professional media teams, and organise supervised learning spaces, all directed at fostering talents that would otherwise go to waste. Production will take place in London and Bedfordshire, but we aim to include other areas as well.

As much work as we have put into Speak&Do already, we need to raise some capital to cover the costs of our first round of content creation until we can attract sponsorship from some leading brands. This is where you come in.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal through this campaign is to put together £70,000. These funds will cover the costs of guest stipends, recording equipment, training facilities, travel expenses, and more, everything that we need to pay for in order to build a self-sustaining production and educational programme delivery team for Speak&Do. To say thanks to all our contributors, we are offering some exciting rewards, including the chance to star in our content, limited-edition merchandise and credits in our content.

The Impact

Motivate. Inspire. Encourage. We want to give young people hope through the work that we are doing at Speak&Do, and we believe in our capacity to change the world one life at a time. Is it going to be easy? Of course not. We all need to come together on this initiative in order to make it a success. Once we hear stories of these young people's growth, though, it will all be worth it!

Risks & Challenges

The way that we see it, there is much more risk inherent to not launching this initiative than there is to launching it. We know that logistical challenges will arise as we move forward through the production and post-production processes, but whatever happens, we will figure out what we need to do to get to the next step. Committed to doing this to create outstanding content andhelping young people in need, we will put forth maximum effort, keeping our contributors updated every step of the way.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to making a monetary contribution to this campaign, you can show your support for Speak&Do by sharing a link to this campaign on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, and any other social media platforms you use. Spread the word about our initiative and let all your friends and family know what we are doing. This is something that everyonecan get on board with, and we don't want to keep it a secret.

Thank you for your time and support.

story:
See the English and Russian texts below!


 1988 թ. երկրաշարժից հետո անհեթեթ կերպով Մինասի Գիշեր որմնանկարի վերևի հատվածը մասամբ կորսվեց, մնաց ներքևի աստղազարդ  երկինքը: Տարիների ընթացքում դա էլ անբարենպաստ պայմաններից սկսեց վնասվել ու այսօր այն կանգնած է ոչնչացման եզրին: Այս պահի դրությամբ նկարի 52-55%-ն է մնացել և այն գտնվում է Գյումրու  նախկին գործարաններից մեկի շենքում։ Եվ սա վերջին, ամենավերջին հնարավորությունն է փրկել որմնանկարը ոչնչացումից, և թույլ չտալ սիրելի Մինասի՝ վերջին չփրկված որմնանկարը վերածվի շինարարական աղբի։
Մինասի որմնանկարները, այդ թվում նաև Գիշերը, հանդիսանում են պետական հուշարձաններ, և պետք է պահպանվեն պետության կողմից, բայց այսօր պետության անելիքները շատ են ու նրա ձեռքերը դեռ չեն հասնում Գիշերին, իսկ մինչև հասնեն, գուցե արդեն շատ  ուշ լինի:
Այսօր, մեր մշակութային արժեքներից մեկը, Գիշերը վտանգված է ոչնչացման և պահանջում է անհապաղ միջամտություն։ Մինասի հիմնդրամը, ընտանիքը և ընկերները նախաձեռնել են ֆոնդերի հավաքագրման այս էջը և ակնկալում են յուրաքանչյուրիդ մասնակցությունը, աջակցությունը և ձեռք մեկնումը մեր մշակութային արժեքի փրկման գործում։ Ցանկացած չափի նվիրատվություն օգտակար է, անգամ $1-ը,  և մենք վստահ ենք, որ միասնական ուժով կարող ենք այս կարևոր խնդրին լուծում գտնել։ Խնդրում ենք նաև կիսվել այս նախաձեռնության մասին ձեր սոցիալական մեդիայի էջերում և խրախուսել ձեր ընկերներին մասնակցել այս կարևոր գործին։ 
Մինասի ընտանիքը, հանձինս Մինասի որդի՝ Արման Ավետիսյանի, պատասխանատու կլինի նվիրատվությունների ստացման, ղեկավարման և հանրային հաշվետվության գործում։

Մինասի Գիշերը նկարի վերականգնման համար հարկավոր է ընդհանուր $26,765: Ֆոնդերի հավաքագրման այս արշավի շրջանակներում հույս ունենք հավաքագրել $10,000-ը, իսկ մնացածը կփորձենք գտնել այլ պետական եւ մասնավոր աղբյուրներից։
Տեսեք ամփոփ նախահաշիվը ստորև, ցանկության դեպքում կտրամադրվի նաև ամբողջական տարբերակը։
Նյութեր։ $5,198
Սարքավորումներ և գործիքներ։ $1,017
Աշխատանքային թիմ/մասնագետներ։ $14,650
Ճանապարհածախս, գիշերակաց։ $2,000
Այլ ծախսեր։ $3,900

After the 1988 Gyumri earthquake, a considerable amount of the upper part of Minas Avetisyan's "Gisher" fresco was lost with the starry sky below being miraculously saved. The fresco has been damaged over the years from unfavorable conditions and vandals. These conditions have led to it falling to pieces. Today, only about 52% of the fresco itself remains. It is located in a former factory building in Gyumri. This will the last opportunity we have to save our beloved Minas' fresco from total destruction. Let’s not allow this last surviving fresco to become construction waste.

Frescos by Minas, including the "Night,", are recognized as state monuments and should be preserved by the government. Unfortunately, Armenia has many urgent needs and projects today. Thus, its hands are unable to reach the "Night." Even if the government decides to do something later, it most likely will be too late.

Today, one of our cultural values, the fresco, “Night”, will disappear from the ravages of time and requires an immediate intervention. The Minas Foundation, together with family and friends have initiated this crowdfunding campaign in hopes that each of YOU will engage, support, and make a contribution to save an important piece of our cultural heritage. Any size of donation amount is helpful, even $1. We believe that together we can find a solution to this important issue.

Please, also share this initiative on your social media pages and encourage your friends to participate in this fundraising campaign.

Arman Avetisyan, the son of Minas Avetisyan, will be responsible for receiving donations, the project management, and public accountability.

A total of $26,765 is needed for the complete restoration of the fresco "Night" by Minas. Within this Indigogo campaign we are planning to raise $10,000 and the rest we hope to get from corporations, foundations, and the government sources.

The summary of the budget is presented below. We'll provide the detailed budget to anybody who is interested in.

Materials։ $5,198

Supplies and tools։ $1,017

Staff & specialists։ $14,650

Travel & per diem։ $2,000

Misc. expenses։ $3,900

После разрушительного землетрясения 1988 года верхняя часть фрески Минаса "Ночь"значительно пострадала, нижняя часть в основном уцелела. В течении последующих лет и эта часть стала постепенно разрушаться из-за плохих условий, и сегодня она стоит перед исчезновением. На сегодняшний день только 52-55% фрески уцелело. Фреска "Ночь" находится в полуразрушённом здании одного из бывших заводов города Гюмри.

Быть может, это последняя возможность спасти то, что ещё можно спасти. Нельзя допустить, чтобы произведение великого мастера превратилось в пыль ...

Все фрески Минаса являются памятниками искусства и охраняются государством . Но сегодня задачи, стоящие перед государством, многочисленны, средств попросту не хватает, а времени на спасение фрески "Ночь" почти не осталось.

Фонд "Минаса", семья художника, а также друзья инициировали эту акцию по сбору необходимых средств во имя спасения последней фрески художника. Мы надеемся на Вашу поддержку и помощь и уверены, что вместе сможем найти решение столь важного и неотложного вопроса. Любое проявленное с вашей стороны внимание и каждый пожертвованный вами 1$ будет чрезвычайно важен для спасения произведения. Просим поделиться по поводу этой инициативы на ваших страницах в социальных сетях.

Семья художника в лице сына Армана Аветисяна будет ответственна за получение пожертвований, а также за их использование и отчётность.

Общая сумма для полного восстановления фрески "Ночь" составляет- 26,765$.

Ниже приводится краткая смета, при желании будет предоставлен полный отчёт.

Материалы: 5,198$

Инструменты и оборудование: 1,017$

Рабочая группа/специалисты: 14,650$

Суточные, расходы на дорогу: 2000$

Непредвиденные расходы: 3900$
story_txt: See the English and Russian texts below! 1988 թ. երկրաշարժից հետո անհեթեթ կերպով Մինասի Գիշեր որմնանկարի վերևի հատվածը մասամբ կորսվեց, մնաց ներքևի աստղազարդ  երկինքը: Տարիների ընթացքում դա էլ անբարենպաստ պայմաններից սկսեց վնասվել ու այսօր այն կանգնած է ոչնչացման եզրին: Այս պահի դրությամբ նկարի 52-55%-ն է մնացել և այն գտնվում է Գյումրու  նախկին գործարաններից մեկի շենքում։ Եվ սա վերջին, ամենավերջին հնարավորությունն է փրկել որմնանկարը ոչնչացումից, և թույլ չտալ սիրելի Մինասի՝ վերջին չփրկված որմնանկարը վերածվի շինարարական աղբի։Մինասի որմնանկարները, այդ թվում նաև Գիշերը, հանդիսանում են պետական հուշարձաններ, և պետք է պահպանվեն պետության կողմից, բայց այսօր պետության անելիքները շատ են ու նրա ձեռքերը դեռ չեն հասնում Գիշերին, իսկ մինչև հասնեն, գուցե արդեն շատ  ուշ լինի:Այսօր, մեր մշակութային արժեքներից մեկը, Գիշերը վտանգված է ոչնչացման և պահանջում է անհապաղ միջամտություն։ Մինասի հիմնդրամը, ընտանիքը և ընկերները նախաձեռնել են ֆոնդերի հավաքագրման այս էջը և ակնկալում են յուրաքանչյուրիդ մասնակցությունը, աջակցությունը և ձեռք մեկնումը մեր մշակութային արժեքի փրկման գործում։ Ցանկացած չափի նվիրատվություն օգտակար է, անգամ $1-ը,  և մենք վստահ ենք, որ միասնական ուժով կարող ենք այս կարևոր խնդրին լուծում գտնել։ Խնդրում ենք նաև կիսվել այս նախաձեռնության մասին ձեր սոցիալական մեդիայի էջերում և խրախուսել ձեր ընկերներին մասնակցել այս կարևոր գործին։ Մինասի ընտանիքը, հանձինս Մինասի որդի՝ Արման Ավետիսյանի, պատասխանատու կլինի նվիրատվությունների ստացման, ղեկավարման և հանրային հաշվետվության գործում։Մինասի Գիշերը նկարի վերականգնման համար հարկավոր է ընդհանուր $26,765: Ֆոնդերի հավաքագրման այս արշավի շրջանակներում հույս ունենք հավաքագրել $10,000-ը, իսկ մնացածը կփորձենք գտնել այլ պետական եւ մասնավոր աղբյուրներից։Տեսեք ամփոփ նախահաշիվը ստորև, ցանկության դեպքում կտրամադրվի նաև ամբողջական տարբերակը։Նյութեր։ $5,198Սարքավորումներ և գործիքներ։ $1,017Աշխատանքային թիմ/մասնագետներ։ $14,650Ճանապարհածախս, գիշերակաց։ $2,000Այլ ծախսեր։ $3,900After the 1988 Gyumri earthquake, a considerable amount of the upper part of Minas Avetisyan's "Gisher" fresco was lost with the starry sky below being miraculously saved. The fresco has been damaged over the years from unfavorable conditions and vandals. These conditions have led to it falling to pieces. Today, only about 52% of the fresco itself remains. It is located in a former factory building in Gyumri. This will the last opportunity we have to save our beloved Minas' fresco from total destruction. Let’s not allow this last surviving fresco to become construction waste.Frescos by Minas, including the "Night,", are recognized as state monuments and should be preserved by the government. Unfortunately, Armenia has many urgent needs and projects today. Thus, its hands are unable to reach the "Night." Even if the government decides to do something later, it most likely will be too late.Today, one of our cultural values, the fresco, “Night”, will disappear from the ravages of time and requires an immediate intervention. The Minas Foundation, together with family and friends have initiated this crowdfunding campaign in hopes that each of YOU will engage, support, and make a contribution to save an important piece of our cultural heritage. Any size of donation amount is helpful, even $1. We believe that together we can find a solution to this important issue.Please, also share this initiative on your social media pages and encourage your friends to participate in this fundraising campaign.Arman Avetisyan, the son of Minas Avetisyan, will be responsible for receiving donations, the project management, and public accountability.A total of $26,765 is needed for the complete restoration of the fresco "Night" by Minas. Within this Indigogo campaign we are planning to raise $10,000 and the rest we hope to get from corporations, foundations, and the government sources.The summary of the budget is presented below. We'll provide the detailed budget to anybody who is interested in.Materials։ $5,198Supplies and tools։ $1,017Staff & specialists։ $14,650Travel & per diem։ $2,000Misc. expenses։ $3,900После разрушительного землетрясения 1988 года верхняя часть фрески Минаса "Ночь"значительно пострадала, нижняя часть в основном уцелела. В течении последующих лет и эта часть стала постепенно разрушаться из-за плохих условий, и сегодня она стоит перед исчезновением. На сегодняшний день только 52-55% фрески уцелело. Фреска "Ночь" находится в полуразрушённом здании одного из бывших заводов города Гюмри.Быть может, это последняя возможность спасти то, что ещё можно спасти. Нельзя допустить, чтобы произведение великого мастера превратилось в пыль ...Все фрески Минаса являются памятниками искусства и охраняются государством . Но сегодня задачи, стоящие перед государством, многочисленны, средств попросту не хватает, а времени на спасение фрески "Ночь" почти не осталось.Фонд "Минаса", семья художника, а также друзья инициировали эту акцию по сбору необходимых средств во имя спасения последней фрески художника. Мы надеемся на Вашу поддержку и помощь и уверены, что вместе сможем найти решение столь важного и неотложного вопроса. Любое проявленное с вашей стороны внимание и каждый пожертвованный вами 1$ будет чрезвычайно важен для спасения произведения. Просим поделиться по поводу этой инициативы на ваших страницах в социальных сетях.Семья художника в лице сына Армана Аветисяна будет ответственна за получение пожертвований, а также за их использование и отчётность.Общая сумма для полного восстановления фрески "Ночь" составляет- 26,765$.Ниже приводится краткая смета, при желании будет предоставлен полный отчёт.Материалы: 5,198$Инструменты и оборудование: 1,017$Рабочая группа/специалисты: 14,650$Суточные, расходы на дорогу: 2000$Непредвиденные расходы: 3900$

story:
Veterinarians, pet groomers, breeders and large pet industry manufacturers all enjoy the benefits of having an organization that represents their interests. 

Pet owners need to have a united voice speaking for them on issues that impact them and their pets. 

The Ontario Pet Owners Network is here to do just that. Welcome to Part 2 of our campaign. 

Case in Point: The College of Veterinarians of Ontario has put a policy in place that unfairly restricts your access to online prescription drugs for your pets.  The Ontario Pet Owners Network is your advocate here. This policy needs to go.

Pet owners of Ontario unite! Join Today.

The Ontario Pet Owners Network is here to:

ADVOCATE 

  • Whenever and wherever policy issues are at issue.
  • Speaking to and for pet owners on policy and regulatory matters that directly impact them.

INFORM

  • As a source of reliable, authoritative information on how to be good pet owners.
  • The best advice on how to buy and care for pets.
  • Ready access to relevant research on what matters and why.

CONNECT

  • As a way to make lasting connections with other pet owners and experts.
  • A forum where pet owners can share ideas, insights, tips, and referrals.
  • As a means to access better deals on goods and services.

HELP PET OWNERS SAVE 

  • Exclusive member discounts on a wide variety of pet products.
  • Yelp-like consumer reviews to create a better sense of transparency around pet goods and services.
  • Information on convenient health, grooming, supply and other services that support the Network’s principles and members.

Join the Movement

If you share our belief that better treatment of pet owners leads to healthier lives for pets, and a better, more equitable pet industry for all, this membership is for you.

Help bring the Ontario Pet Owners Network to life and level the playing field for pet owners across Ontario. In the first part of our campaign we raised $540, we're hoping to continue this momentum! 

Become a founding member today:
1-Year Family membership at a prelaunch price of $ 30.00 (Regular Price $ 35.00)

2-Year Family membership at a prelaunch price of $ 45.00 (Regular Price $ 70.00)

We look forward to you joining us!


To learn more about the Ontario Pet Owners Network visit www.OPON.ca or contact ontariopetowners@gmail.com 

If you're interested in simply supporting our cause, we'd also love to hear from you.

story:
Who are we?

Carson - Longtime community activist, technology professional, and Entrepreneur

Joe - Longtime social benefit CEO, venture capitalist, and Entrepreneur

Carson and Joe have been friends for 20 years and have shared a passion for social benefit and business. Seeing the radical decline of empathy in our culture, the duo set out to find a solution that combines the reach and leverage of technology, the aim of a social benefit business and with the goal of bringing people together face to face for the pure purpose of one person unconditionally helping another person.

We want to change the world

Contributors to this project will help us change the world, and at scale. People are fundamentally good, and in the quickening of the pace of modern life, it is easy to drift into “solipsism” or be more self, than other, centered.

Contributors to the platform will be funding the development of a solution that is designed to counter this trend, by helping people find 60 minutes a week in their busy schedules and connecting them with another person who they can help. Mowing a lawn, picking up groceries for someone who is homebound, helping someone write a resume,  or simply watching a movie with someone who shares a similar interest and is need of a companion.

Everyone faces a difficult path and has pain and challenges in their lives. On top of that, life is short, and the greatest expression of humanity is to actively, and selflessly, take the time and effort to help another without an expectation of a reward. (The secret is the feeling of satisfaction of having helped another without expectation of reward, is the reward.)

Help us build Benevolently. Help us help others, and generate more kindness in the world.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $65,000 take the platform to the next level so we can deploy it to a larger group of users on the pathway to a final launch.

$25,000 for our mobile platform development (IOS and Android)

$10,000 for our web platform BETA2 (matching capabilities, social media integrations)

$10,000 for operational costs for the next 12 months (servers, 3rd party applications)

$20,000 for marketing costs

Funds will go towards the development of the platform in the order listed above. We will continue fundraising on additional platforms and through traditional methods until we have met our funding goals.

The Impact

Your contribution will go to helping others, at scale, indefinitely. There are millions and millions of people who are suffering and need help. They need assistance, they need companionship, all of which requires compassion and a willingness by others to help them. Benevolently will help to surface those people with those needs and to connect them to the people that can help them.

Our goal is to make the platform multilingual, and multicultural so that it can scale worldwide.

Why will we make this happen?

Both Joe and Carson have a track record of getting results and bringing things into reality when they weren’t there before.

Community civic engagement, fundraisers, social benefit businesses, technology builds, and more have all been successfully created under Joe’s and/or Carson’s leadership and wherewithal. This is the first project we are working on together, and we are both very impassioned by it.

What risks do we face?

The primary risk for the platform is to build the ongoing activity of the Givers to continue to give over time. We plan on addressing this by focusing on the “matching engine” in the platform so that we can very skillfully use technology to make the opportunities and their execution, very seamless into their schedules. We can make it easy and lower the barriers to its execution, we think that the good feelings generated in people after they have helped someone else, combined with a simple/smooth way of taking advantages of those opportunities, will be our formula for long-term success.

Benevolently is in the process of gaining B Corporation certification.

Benevolently is a Delaware Benefit Corporation.

story:
Short Summary

We are reaching out to all Freestyle Friday’s artists, volunteers, patrons, and the greater community. We need you to help us create the next stage and platform for our event; a weekend long camp out. Freestyle Fridays has been running for 2 years and it has built a reputation as a positive space for hip-hop and creative artists to flex and connect. This October we want to take the community to the next level. This isn't just for the dedicated heads, we've got a schedule packed with creative activities where anyone can make their own art or learn some new skills. We want everyone to feel included.

The secret venue within an hour of Brissy has large grassy areas, shady trees, fire pits and limited neighbours. It's under an hour from Brisbane, but if you prefer us to chauffer you from the closest train station and back, pre-purchase a bus ticket when your getting your festival and food tickets.

The location of the camp is need to know, and only ticket holders need to know, so when you learn the secret, keep it.

 

If you would like to be involved or have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact us. There are no silly questions, and we would rather you ask.
